However, the script of this film seems quite weak in places and the post-rescue scenes are bordering on unbelievable;  The 'happy' ending appears as it was tacked on, almost as an afterthought.  And just what was the deal with the whales ? Wait until it comes out on video, or leave after the plane crash...

title: Amazing acting, disappointing story.
review: The acting was amazing, and I believe it will garner Tom Hanks his next oscar.  The film, overall, disappointed both my wife and me, as we were expecting more from the story.  More detail, more scenes from the island, more about how he survived.  Most of all, we want to know what was in the package he delivered to the woman in Shamrock, TX.

title: very good
review: For once hollywood can entertain us, with out the use of profanity,nudity,or violence. It was a very good movie with lots of action, and suspence,this surely is a oscar nomination, for both Best Movie and Best lead actor,

title: Disappointed!
review: Tom Hanks' performance was excellent but the movie was boring.  I'm not sure what the message was.  Cast Away offered little action and not much entertainment and certainly no message.  Helen Hunt's role was minimal at best.  She did a good acting job but overall Cast Away is insignificant. Wait for the video.

title: Okay, but didn't do as much with story as they should've done
review:
I really wanted to see this film with all the hype. I am a great fan of Hanks, and tremendously enjoyed Forest Gump and Apollo 13. However a word of warning firstly! Don't go to see this movie if you are flying any time soon. That part of the film was well done, i.e. the crash scene.

I was expecting great things of this movie, as it had an all star cast of Hanks and Helen Hunt. It was an average movie and rather disappointing as they could have made a lot more of the plot possibilities. There were alot of open ends, the movie was slow. They don't seem to have made the most of potential plot possibilities. The script seemed rather weak, a pity as Hanks' acting was very good.

You come away from the movie feeling a wee bit cheated. My feeling is okay, go and see it, but its not something I would rave about

title: Not perfect, but wonderful
review:
I saw 'Cast Away' last night and must say that I was very impressed. The fact that I am a fan of Tom Hanks probably helped me enjoy the film, because I doubt anyone who does not like Tom Hanks would enjoy 'Cast Away' being the fact that he is almost the entire film.

'Cast Away' is far from a perfect film, as there are some minor, and a few major, holes in the story and sadly the script is not always up to scratch. To be honest, I was a little surprised that the film has so many flaws, given the fact that the Australian media have been so full of praise. In my opinion however, Tom Hanks carries the film beyond these flaws and script letdowns, and while Helen Hunt is not given much to do, she is wonderful in the small screen time she has.

The first 25-30 minutes of the film is essentially fairly dull, however it has a certain edge to it created by the viewer already knowing what is install for Hank's character. The plane crash is one of the most amazing things I have ever seen on film. I was actually not looking forward to the plane crash footage because I figured it would be nothing more than something the audience would have to endure before the real story begun. However, it was so good that I actually felt myself tensing up, which really say's something about the footage because I rarely respond like that to anything on screen.

The cast away' part of the story is equally brilliant, because it could so easily have been unbearably boring. I think many reviewers on this website are correct in their disliking of the way in which it cuts to four years later', as it does feel as if Zemeckis took the easy way out in this respect. My only other complaint about the cast away' part of the story is Hank's escape off the island, which did seem a little rushed in execution and generally not as dramatic (with the exception of one moment, but I won't completely spoil it) as the events that had taken place before. However, this part of the film is by in large incredible, and a work of pure genius from both Zemeckis, but particularly Hanks.

Finally, many reviewers here have complained about the last part of the film, many suggesting that it went on too long. However, I did not find myself bored or restless during the last part of the film because I was generally interested in finding out what happens to Hank's character as he tries to re-enter society. My complaint about the last part has more to do with the script lulls, because the film does not answer some of the bigger questions regarding this transition. However, like all of the weaker spots in the film, Hanks carries the audience past them and it is his presence that makes this one of the best films since American Beauty (released around the same time last year)

I truly hope that Hanks gets his third Oscar for his role in this film, because quite simply, I have not seen a better performance in any film over the last 12 months.

title: Good but ....
review: Entertaining movie if you can accept waterlogged packages with dry contents (ink on cards doesn't even smear), no ill effects from being pulled under water then surfacing rapidly (any SCUBA divers in the crowd?), and a current that pulls his raft one way and his "friend" another. Otherwise, another great performance from Tom Hanks. Worth a see.

title: Bravo!
review: CastAway is as strong and deep in storyline as any movie I can remember. Its gripping, happy, sad, and really not long enough.  Near to the last scene (not going to spoil it in discussion) should have expanded more...It is really hard to sit through the film and not feel teary eyed.  Tom Hanks has really established himself as a phenom. actor.  Definitely gonna be one of my DVD must owns.

title: A sabbathic experience
review: I saw it hours before I wrote this lines and I'm still feeling exhausted as I cried for about 2/3 of the picture. It's a cleansing, sabbathic and religious experience watching this movie. Not because it mentions the word God or other divine entity (note the funeral) but it has faith and the character believes in itself even when he thinks he no longer exists as a human. Beginning with a crossroad somewhere in the middle of an American desert (instantly reminder of "North by Northwest") the movie starts within a minute in a frantic pace of a FedEx box traveling (physically and with the camera) from America to Russia in another well-remembered voyeur-voyage by Zemeckis. Frantic or not, we soon discover the meaning of TIME and SPACE in this multiple-paced well-placed cameras showing the exact spots of what Time and Space are supposed to stand in the castaway's life. Zemeckis' twisting and turning views in this movie are sometimes experiencing what the character does, other times before and after him and we enjoy more viewing this movie as a voyeur (didn't Hitchcock teach us a lesson about the art of cinema?) rather than what's going to happen in the plot which is a bit secondary. Then, there are the boxes. The Pandora boxes, only this time what's inside them loses power for what they are and steps in another dimension of their usefulness. They act as tools and sometimes as characters to solve the problems of one's Cast Away. They expand time (the volleyball "ball") and produce space (the blades of the ice rollerskate). Finally, the blood. Lots of it. Not like a sign of death but incredibly, as a flux of life that the castaway uses to generate his feelings (Wilson or Son of Will) or to survive (the blood spill when he's making fire) and, thus returning to the religious thoughts in the start of the comment, he must need to sacrifice his body in order to (re)gain spiritual meaning about being alive. Note detail: he only eats after a long time drinking coconut MILK! Crossroads are exactly where this post-modern urban castaway stands in the beginning of the movie regarding his multiple choices. Career/marriage, workplace/home to name a few. Eventually he'll get to make one in a limit situation: the girlfriend's watch opposed to the lifeguard-waistcoat. It's a nice ellipse when he ends up in the place that was only known by the viewer in the beginning, having to choose a course in the vast desert. And this time he really chooses! P.S.: I hope Tom Hanks will deservedly be the first man to win three awards for leading role in the history of Oscars!

title: What a great show!
review: What a good movie.  The display of Tom Hanks' independent struggle to survive is quite moving.  I even cried when Wilson floated away, and I never cry during movies.  Wasn't too long, and wasn't too short.  Tom Hanks is almost unparallelled in the industry.

title: Thought Provoking
review:
I don't know what you've heard but most of the critics are raving while many ordinary folks seem to be rather disappointed. I read one review by a member of the public who was moaning about a poor script, god only knows what he was expecting when it's a story about a guy stuck for years on his own on an island!!

Anyway to state the obvious and provide some perspective this is not a special effects movie, but the scenery is impressive and the cinematography is quite often excellent. The script is of course thin but the small amount of character interaction is largely convincing and you can relate to the two main characters.

To sum up, this movie is trying to make you think and sympathise, if you just sit and stare at the screen with brain disengaged you will either fall asleep or just get incredibly bored.

The film wasn't exactly what i had expected but the more i thought about it afterwards the more i realised how good a film it was. In terms of making you step back and assess your life this film is almost as good as It's a Wonderful Life, it's just a shame that the effect wears off.

title: Tom Hanks does it again!
review: He found the island that I've wished my whole life I could wash up on...just kidding.  But it would be nice to get away for a while, wouldn't it??? "Cast Away" was great, I think.  Although like so many others it took me a minute to figure out why he took 4 years to escape--duh, the Port-a-Potty provided him with a sail; got him past the reef & breakers, & out on the open sea (my apologies to anyone who has already mentioned this fact, I didn't really read all 312 reviews before mine.)  This has been such a bad year overall for films, it was great to see such a wonderful piece of drama.

title: Wonderful...
review: All i have to say is that this is by far my favorite movie of this year . It was very well made and had a great cast. The trailer makes it look kinda hokey but it is really great. DEFINITELY worth the money . So go see this movie right now!

title: well up with some tears and experience a moment of passing profundity
review: Stories about being stranded on a desert island have an elemental appeal to the human imagination, so it seems appropriate that the premier spinner of high tech cinematic fables  Robert Zemeckis - would step up to the plate with his 21st century spin on the tale. Interestingly the title Cast Away is rendered as two separate words. Could this be a way to emphasize that the cast of the movie is away for most of the film.  Perhaps it's because cast member Tom Hanks is also a producer and collaborator on the film, hinting that `cast away' may be a little like `anchors aweigh' where  `the new' Hollywood launches another tale of Everyman for a politically, morally, and spiritually confused and transitioning time. It's time to take stock of ourselves in our high paced world. Who better to take us through that journey than the common man du jour, Mr. Hanks. Like Forrest Gump, or with anything featuring Tom Hanks or directed by Zemeckis, the film has quality and integrity. Life is struggle, we all go too fast, we don't value the really important things in life, love is powerful and enduring, fate works in strange ways, life is what you make it. Their themes are crystal clear, bordering on painfully obvious. That's OK, too, because great effects and fabulous scenery in service to good commercial filmmaking is virtuous and inevitably appealing, not to mention boffo box office. The three part structure of the film is therefor entirely appropriate. Those who feel the rescue section (I won't say what happens  just in case) doesn't work, miss the purpose of the storytelling. It is not created to make us leave the theater in an existential quandary, but to be entertained, well up with some tears, experience a moment of passing profundity, and briefly ponder a few big questions.  Expecting the film to do otherwise is like having Johnny Appleseed sow his seeds across the America only to find out they never sprouted.  The film's artificiality is part of its appeal. Perhaps that's why I find myself watching the credits until the very end. I needed to find out whether the large crab on the spear caught by the Hank's character at in the beginning of his island stay was real or animatronics. It was animatronics.

title: Very good movie!!
review: Before I saw this...all of my friends were telling me how great that it was. I had nothing to do so I decided to see it...I mean Tom Hanks has never been in a bad movie, and Robert Zemekis is a good director. I was not disapointed. I think that this is one of the best movies of the year. The movie starts out good and keeps getting better till the end. Some people said that the movie was too long, but I disagree. I think that it was the perfect length; any longer would have been boring, and any shorter and there would have been something left out. Also, some people didn't like the ending, but I thought that it fit perfectly at what Chuck (Tom) said earlier in the film. I really recomend that everyone sees this. It a really good movie that I think everyone will enjoy. After this I am going to get a volleyball  and name it Wilson. hehehe just kidding.  10/10!!!

title: Liked it a lot
review: This is a great movie and Tom Hanks deserves much praise for it. His acting is excellent and his physical transformation very impressive. Helen Hunt's performance was sort but especially in the second part very good. I think the movie was very realistic in the scenes of Tom on the island, overall the movie works well.

title: Superb Film - Shameful Ending...SPOILERS AHEAD
review: Not knowing if I could endure Tom Hanks on a desert island for an hour or so, I decided to take the plunge and go see this movie - and what a film! Right from the start I was intrigued how the film was going to pan out, waiting for that all exciting plane crash which I'd heard so much about and boy, how that didn't dissapoint. It was terrifying! So much so, that I found myself willing it to crash to get it over with but for 10mins we were subjected to a horrifying rollercoaster of a flight with the end result seeming to take a lifetime to come and when it did it wasn't over. In the sea with just a liferaft, Hanks' life was still in danger and when night finally turned into morning I breathed easy again. The island was beautiful and this must have some of the best filming sequences I have ever seen in a movie. Even though there is only one person on screen for the majority of the film and virtually no music I did not find myself for one minute being bored or losing my concentration - it was fabulous........but then things started to go wrong. The screen went black for no reason and the words 'Four years later' appeared on the screen.....what???? Just as we were settling in to see how he would cope we skipped forward four years and had to endure a bravado escape plot which quite frankly should have happened three years earlier. Putting that aside though, I went with the flow until he was found that is. Ok, we knew he would have to get back and he did but when he did and Helen Hunt decided not to take him back even without seeing him - THAT'S WHEN THE FILM SHOULD HAVE ENDED!!!!! In the lounge of FedEx headquarters NOT half an hour later. We had to endure an extra three or four tacky schmultzee scenes which had no place or need in this film and in my opinion turned this film from a superb piece of cinema history to a absolute sham and cop-out. Thank god though they didn't get back together in a tear jerking reunion. Apart from all this though, I'm awarding this film 8/10 for sheer guts and innovation. And no, I do not think Tom Hanks deserves an oscar for this!!!!!!

title: Think of people and things that you can't live without....
review:
I watched the movie one night while my sister was busy preparing her graduation admission exam in another room. After it was over, it really took me a while to regain myself, and then I came up to my sister and hugged her closely and tightly, "Thank God. We're here with each other. And Xixi (her name), you know I love you."

Probably nobody can truly present how a man would behave when being "cast away". But I think Tom Hanks did a good job in this movie - in both unimaginable and imaginable scenes.

What actually is this story about? the basic needs of mankind? the value of life itself? the courage to survive despair? hope and love the only salvation? the beauty of our everyday life that should not be neglected? how to define misfortune and fortune? ....

Points for us to ponder and many things for us to be grateful. And to say, to do, to love, to experience, to live our life to the fullest...

title: Tom Hanks carried this movie!!!
review: Tom Hanks carried this movie.  I am not going to give you the run down of the plot or the script, lets just say that they're rather poor.  But the acting on all levels were, I thought, rather excellent.  There was about an hour and a half of no background music, just Tom hanks acting.  So it was going it was going to be him that makes or breaks the movie, and he succeeded.

title: Oscar... meet Tom Hanks & Robert Zemeckis...
review:
Tom & Bob... meet ol' Osc...

This scenario would only happen if Tom, Oscar and Robert all had amnesia. Why? Because the threesome got acquainted back in 1995 when Hanks and Zemeckis worked together on Forrest Gump. And Believe me-you, the magic is still there. I just caught the film and let me tell ya... it's worth every penny or frank or pound or rubel or whatever; because where ever you might live, You will love this film. Being trapped on a desert isle is an old fashioned story I know, yet so is a love story, and so is a story of good vs. evil. And those stories show up all the time. Why? Because we like em. We'll see who's right come this March. Oh yes, we will see indeed.

title: Not bad but can be better
review:
The movie itself is good, story is excellent the thing is that there are lots of movies that shown someone or somebody stranded on an island.

Some movie critics might not find this interesting cause even myself have seen lots of movie which similar like this. The only thumb up is the story which can be say, excellent writing.

title: Riveting, against all odds
review:
PLOT SPOILERS WARNING

You have to give it to the man. Bob Zemeckis, who I consider one of the best directors in Hollywood, lost some of my appreciation after the dreadful "Contact" (If even he wasn't able to save that script, maybe it's because it was so bad that nobody could have), but he has proved this year that he is well and truly back on track, first with "What Lies Beneath" and now with this virtuoso tour-de-force. To keep the spectator glued to the screen for two hours when all you have is one man and a volleyball in a deserted island is almost defying logic, yet Zemeckis manages to pull it off thanks to excellent timing and rhythm, a phenomenal setting (where is this island? I want to go there!), beautifully photographed, and a fabulous, Oscar-worthy performance from Hanks (again... these two were made for each other), portraying the amazing odyssey of endurance and self-discovery of a man who had lost sight of the important things in life. In fact, I was enjoying it so much that I wasn't sure I wanted the poor guy to escape from the island, I wanted to keep watching his adventures...!

I loved the relationship of Chuck with his alter ego Wilson, which becomes as real a character as you could wish for (in fact, I can think of a couple of action movie stars who could probably take acting tips from it...), and was truly saddened when Chuck is forced to abandon him. The fact that Zemeckis could extract so much sympathy from an inanimate object, a face painted on a ball, reminds me of how menacing Kubrick could make a round, red and yellow light look in "2001..", or how much Lucas charmed us with R2-D2's grumpy character, even if we couldn't understand anything he said...

I also loved the fact that, in keeping with his character, Chuck maintained his "integrity", what he considered his essence, at least for the first few days, by not opening the boxes. It did bug me a bit that, when the circumstances force him to do so, he left one of them unscathed to serve as a symbol, a reminder of his former self and his mission in life (as the note says, "This box saved my life"). I thought it was a little bit unrealistic, and I was fearing some terrible but daft final revelation about it ("look! a cellphone!"); but in the end it turns out that what the box contains is not important ("Pulp Fiction" style), but what it represents, which is not only his mission, but his new future, "brought in by the tide.." (If he hadn't saved it, he would never had met his future partner... come on, did anybody really not get the hint of where he was going after the final scene?). Nice final touch.

All in all, a beautiful film and a great performance by Hanks and Zemeckis. They were robbed of a bunch of Oscars, if you ask me.

title: An excellent piece of work
review: It was really intriguing to see how this film can succeed using such a basic principle. A large part of the film is carried solehandedly by Hanks, whereas there is no dialogue to speak of, no dramatic tension in the traditional sense, no score to accompany the imagery. Yet Cast Away keeps us completely involved. I'm not exactly his greatest fan, but i think Hanks is to be commended. He really deserved the critical acclaim for this role. I think it is terrific to see such great names (Hanks & Zemeckis) taking these great risks in filmmaking. (Unfortunately) I rarely see this kind of experimental filmmaking in mainstream hollywood. The film's ending leaving us a bit puzzled, perhaps the story could have been resolved in a better way and i never cared much for Helen Hunt, however all in all this is still a great piece of work. The plane-crash sequence deserves special mention, as it is truly spectacular as well as frighteningly real.

title: Excellent movie with BIG flaws
review: This is an entertaining and visually stunning movie that has something terribly wrong with it.  That something is inconsistency.  I think both writer and director contributed to the good and the bad.  Again and again, ideas of pure genius are mixed with unlikely  even irrational  points that are impossible to accept.  For starters: could a Caucasian spend 4 years in the blazing sun of a tropical island and come away with crusted lips and no trace of sunburn?  Not even a tan?  Tom Hanks is good and likeable, as always.  But he carries the picture only in the sense that for much of it no one else is onscreen.  Although his role calls for him to do lots of unusual things, they're really script stunts, not acting.  He needs that talent only sporadically.  For me, the film's 3 big plusses are the plane crash, the photography and the story's conclusion.  The crash at sea is seen wholly from inside the craft, from the passengers' point of view.  (It's reminiscent of Hitchcock's masterful clipper crash in `Foreign Correspondent' 60 years earlier.)   The photography by Don Burgess keeps us in precisely the right place every second.  His camera is often at water level yet  thanks to digital work, I assume  there's never a drop on the lens.  The movie ends in an ideal location and on a perfect note of indecision and nearly limitless possibilities.  Among the film's best bits is Wilson, Tom's volley ball companion, whose loss is heartbreaking.  For a good and skillful movie, however, far too many questions remain.  The island's beach is littered with FedEx packages from the plane's cargo, yet it seems days before Tom even thinks to look in them for useful items.  Why? (Eventually, nearly everything proves to be valuable.)  He also takes too long to secure the inflatable life raft that got him from the crash site to the island.  And once that's lost in an unsuccessful attempt to get away, ages pass before he even thinks of trying to BUILD some sort of escape craft.  I just don't believe it.  Among the dumber script flaws is Tom's toothache.  With all the genuine crises facing a castaway, this affliction seems contrived and superfluous.  But despite the irritating lapses in `Cast Away,' the splendid good points outweigh the clumsy ones, and best parts are unforgettable.  8 stars out of 10.

title: Better than I thought
review:
Sometimes I think Tom Hanks gets nominated for too many awards so I was very skeptical of a long film about a Robinson Crusoe type film.

Sometimes it's nice to be surprised. The direction was unconventional by focussing on his island stay rather than flashing back all the time and Hanks gives what must be one of his best performances, making a very credible loner interacting with a volleyball!!

You come out with an invigoration of the human spirit determined to have a fulfilled life - whether we ever do is another issue.

title: Saw it, was okay, wanted to FedEx something.
review:
*Some possible spoilers here, but none that haven't been given away so far.*

How come no-one here so far has mentioned the sheer amount of product placement in this film? It goes beyond the point of silliness (like the Nokia phones on Charlie's Angles) to the point where a FedEx package is the reason for the main character to live.

First thing you see is a FedEx truck. Hank's character works for FedEx. FedEx parcels wash up on his island.

But, maybe, this is a statement. Hanks has given himself totally to this corporate world, even so far as to leave at Christmas to go with a delivery. Maybe his island is his means to escape from this.

Fat chance. FedEx parcels wash up regularly, leaving a corporate brand on a uninhabited island.

But by the time Hanks makes his escape (c'mon, you know he gets back, it's in the damn trailer.) he's left everything behind. His Maglite torch has run out. His clothes are now just unrecognizable shreds. The one parcel he has left unopened has had all the branding washed off it. Maybe that's a metaphor for him? Maybe. So off he goes, a better person... ...until he raises his sail. He's painted a FedEx logo on it.

Damn you Hanks.

I think I'm being to harsh on it. Maybe reading the book No Logo isn't helping.

Maybe this is it's statement. Thanks to his loyalty to the corporation, Hanks looses everything and is left just as alone as he was on that island.

Maybe it is subversive.

Maybe.

(See? I got through a whole review without loads of !!!!!! and no caps. Learn, people, please.)

title: Amazingly dull..... a complete waste of time
review:
The volleyball had a better role.....

Why does hollywood have to constantly dole out symbolic garbage? EVERY scene is this movie is a cheap attempt at profoundness..... Thanks for nothing......

People were crying in the sold out movie theater when I watched this film, yes it was that bad, I have laughed at serious movies before but I think Zemeckis was really looking for a comedy in this because I laughed the entire way through it.....

The cave men were able to make fire faster...... rubbing a couple of sticks together when you had the flashlight lense, and this guy is supposed to be some upper up smart guy in FEDex?

It takes him 4 years to decide to leave the island?

A port-a-potty ? give me break.... he had the rescue raft there on the island with him, yes it had holes in the inflatable part but the bottom was intact and would have made a better sail......

What happened to the toothache?

What happened to the ring box he gave to Helen "I have 10 seconds of screen time" Hunt?

For being in such a sad sorry shape for four years he sure recovered quick and looked as good as new after his "rescue"

A very overrated movie. Zemeckis should get the booby award for worst film.....

I saw Forrest Gump and Saving Private Ryan and was very impressed with Hanks in both, but this movie washed that impression right out. Falls right into line with the great Costner bombs: waterworld, postman, for love of the game, 13 days, etc....

My advice: If you have to see this film, let a friend rent it and then only when it's on the $00.99 shelf.......

title: A movie that chooses the road of superficiality
review:
I was very disappointed in this movie. I expected a decent look into the challenges of living in utter isolation, having to survive without modern acoutrements, and a lot of reflection on one's place in the universe. Oh no. This film, whenever confronted with the option, chooses the road of superficiality over depth.

Once we get past the deeply Republican yuppie fantasy of "ideal existence" and onto the island, we would expect, at least after a while, a little reflection on the part of our protagonist. But, for a film whose star is so eager to declare that "nothing happens" in its middle section, we are treated to unending survival tips and adventures at the expense of any reflection. This is a beautiful island, surely anyone there would have some moments of appreciating the stillness and natural wonder of the island. Well, not here. Surely after four years Hanks would have developed his own ways, his own joys and sorrows, new abilities he's proud of, or good at, but we just don't see them. His emotional range remains, for the whole of the island portion of the film, sad and sadder. We're supposed to believe that after he returns to civilization that there's a part of him left on that island-- well, based on this movie, he never really seems to BE on the island, he's always a yuppie visitor, and doesn't seem to engage in his environment. This movie could have been much more powerful if it chose to really engage in the loneliness and despair that one would feel after giving up on civilization and realizing one may be alone for the rest of one's life. Hanks is a fine actor unhampered by vanity, but here what we're seeing is a movie star dropped off on a set every morning. The movie's depth never rises above the level of "Dude, what if you were like, trapped on an island? Man, like, what would you DO? That would sure suck." And that's the one statement this film seems to make: being alone in the universe pretty much sucks. Hey, Thanks Tom, you're giving us pearls.

There are a lot of other details that give the film away as a sham. If I was standed on a tropical island, the first thing I would do is look for the resort on the other side. Tom shouts a few "Hello's," then assumes that there's no one there. At one point he climbs up to the summit--at this point a 360-degree pan could have worked wonders, but uh-uh, not here. I still think there's a Club Med a half-mile away that Tom just never bothered to look for. He also never really seems to explore the island--and after four years, don't you think you'd take a little field trip? Also, after four years, wouldn't you have built yourself more than a few spears? Tom can't get off the island because of the reef off the section of beach he refuses to leave--maybe he could have paddled around to see if there was a break in the reef? Oh, I guess not. This is what I mean when I say this film never really engages with the reality of being on the island, and robs itself of the seriousness it so desperately asks of its audience.

I have read a book of true accounts of people stranded on islands ("Great Shipwrecks and Castaways," it's still in print, and it's excellent, so look for it if this interests you), and a book on how to survive if you must drift for days on a raft, and I know that the real problem Tom is going to face once his portasan blows away is exposure to the sun. But that problem is apparently not convenient for this film to explore, so it just pretends like it doesn't exist. This film asks you to reflect only on the problems of nature that Hollywood can easily solve, all others simply do not exist.

A SPOILER IN THIS NEXT SECTION: But the real mistake this movie makes, in which it betrays both itself and its audience, is to virtually cancel out ALL emotional resonance it might have attained by having a hot babe appear out of nowhere in the final two minutes to make everything okay. This development is at once disappointing and disgusting. Disappointing in that all the sadness we've built up for Hanks is INSTANTLY ERADICATED by the convenient appearance of a new "chick" to make his life complete, disgusting in the suggestion that Helen Hunt's character, who we've built up such a respect and reverence for, can simply be replaced by an almost identical "hot chick" (this one has RED hair though! And besides, Hunt never amounted to much anyway). So, as an audience, we are left to assume that Hank's character really IS stupifyingly superficial, and that the only connection he really had to Hunt, all that time on the island, is that he needed some babe in his life. Hunt, or someone else, it doesn't matter. This puts a nasty taste in my mouth now when I think about Hanks and Zemeckis as PEOPLE. But aside from that, I am surprised that they would so completely betray the film they've obviously expended so much effort on.

All in all, a deeply Republican film. It prods us to look deep inside ourselves and ask: "What would we do if one day we didn't have an SUV and a pager?" But, the movie says, don't worry about not having a woman around, they're a dime a dozen, and they're all the same.

Bleech!

--- Check out website devoted to bad and cheesy movies: www.cinemademerde.com

title: Best film since The Insider
review:
I read some really bad reviews before I had the opportunity to see the film myself; This is not only a good story that makes you think about the way you live your life at the moment but also takes its time to develop real characters and has btw. the most realistic airplane crash I've ever seen;

nobody's talking your ears off ( not much dialogue when you're alone on an island ...), you only get the actor's physical reaction expressing his inner state of mind and Tom Hanks is just doing a terrific job !!! No other movie this year - except The Insider and perhaps Gladiator - had me leaving the theater still thinking about what I had just seen.

title: Definitely worth it!
review: I thought this was a great film. Tom Hanks was brilliant. I liked the way the director brought in an element of comedy in a film which was really quite serious. Before I saw the film I was told that it wasn't great but I always believe in giving films a chance and I'm glad I did with this one. The only fault I found with it was that the ending was a bit dragged out. I would definitely recommend this film to anyone who doesn't mind sitting for 2hrs 20mins!!

title: The title is 2 words.
review:
I didn't catch it until I looked at the poster after I saw the film. The director, "Dr.Z", is a genius for giving a bizarre quasi-sequel to Forrest Gump. Tom Hanks as Gump meets all these people through out history with little effort and takes part in the entire U.S. experience - Chuck Noland is a man that has to do with everyone, 6 degrees wise, with everyone in the world (he's with FedEx). Then is not connected with another human soul. His wonderful kaleidescope of people and places take place on a microcosim of himself. In the time he is away the things like Strife (Surviving & War), friends (Wilson & Bubba), and redemption (Jenny & Kelly) happen as can be seen on Nolan's appearance.

Dr.Z has always shown us stories of infinite contact and communication of the human spirit whether through time, space, etc. and now the human spirit of isolation. Surviving one's self is ultimate to the human experience. One who is Cast Away is banished, or forced not into nothing - but onto oneself (for better or worse). This is what this Movie is at. Go Dr. Z!!!!

P.S. Wilson can also be seen as stife since friends and family are like blood and so is Wilson if you get down to it. Who else do you bleed for?

title: Deeper than you might think
review: After reading others' reviews I ask myself "Did they miss it?" or maybe this movie is not for everybody. There are not many movies like this out there. I really appreciated not having any music to "add" to the intense scenes, it made the movie more real. There is also a very interesting and deep emotional side to the movie that made a definite impact on me... I don't mind the jumping around and not showing every detail... the important things were shown. He survived the physical and it was made to look easy compared to surviving the emotional. To love deeply and to let go... great tragedy, and real living. My words do not do justice to this great film, 9/10.

title: Excellent acting by Hanks (as usual) and a moving story....
review: It takes a heck of a strong screenplay and a great actor to hold a viewers interest in watching how a man struggles to maintain his sanity while being cast away alone on a small island for years. I was moved by the story, and Hanks plays the part beautifully, perhaps as well as or better than any other of his acting peers.  My only disappointment came with the very end.

title: Here on Gilligan's Isle.....Skipperrrr!!!
review:
I know this was meant to be a read dead serious flick, but I kept on saying to myself, at crucial points in this-'Skipper!! Gilligan!' or 'What would the Professor do? Why take that rubber dinghy and the hose and fashion up a MacGyver style Entertainment Center!'

SPOILERS BELOW!!

Try as I might, I hadda hard time getting as into the characters' pain as they wanted us too. Sure I winced come dentist time, or when he cuts his feet or whatever, and yeah I was glad when he made the fire-but--it seemed somehow or other to be superficial. I didn't for a minute believe that he could make it out into the Wide open Pacific the way he did on his log raft without either starving to death, being drowned or just plain winding up on another island. Coincidence time I know counts in flix, but still...passing over a shipping lane at that very moment a freighter is going by? Surrre...

I liked some of the how-does-Tom-make-it bits, him exploring the island, or making fire or clothes or getting the fish or whatever, but the whole Robinson Crusoe thing has been done before, and I think we could have seen more of him there and less with the tacked on ending. I wanted to know him somewhat more, heck Wilson there had as much to say as Tom did at times.

And the ending-okay Helen Hunt can't stand to leave her new family, but at the same time, claims she wants Tom still, despite her refusal to see him at the airport. What gives there?? Why weren't we shown more of his transition on the ship then back home, heck even Time and CNN seemed to cover it, surely we the audience deserved that too.

Now I liked the fact Lari White(I knew it was a country singer, thought for sure it was Pam Tillis, oh well...)made a cameo at the end, and that Tom's fate is uncertain as that of Terry Anderson's, for example was back in '91 when he came back, but-something is missing here. Someone here points out that Tom and Helen oughta had more to say to one another. I agree.

Acting and production values of course are all fine, but-the punchline ain't that great. Maybe they shoulda ended the flick about the time the boat finds him? I woulda...

*** outta ****-Tom and Zemeckis are too good to cut it any lower, but Lord knows the writers make it tempting...

title: Tom Hanks is brilliant
review:
Cast Away: ***1/2

"Cast Away" is very close to brilliance. Tom Hanks is an excellent actor and he gets to prove that in this movie. Also, there is some beautiful scenery.

The movie is about Tom Hanks' character, who is a Fed Ex man, getting lost on a deserted island. He is on a Fed Ex plane and it goes down. Some of the mail washed up on shore. A volley ball named Wilson befriends him. It was very neat seeing how he did things. He made shoes and fire and other stuff that you need to see the movie for. I would go crazy on the island. He occasionally does, but maintains sanity for the most part. Before he left to get on the plane he had a girlfriend whom he loved. She is played by Helen Hunt. She isn't in the movie much which is sort of a disapointment.

Tom Hanks is brilliant. He is a great actor who has a lot of talent. He makes the movie work. Showing off his acting skills and making it look easy. This must have been a difficult film to make. But through all that his talent keeps going on.

The reason I did not award it four stars is the ending. It was vague. All dramas end that way, but this was unclear. There were so many possibilities. Oh, well.

The island that the movie was based on was beautiful. Throughout the movie it is a feast for the eyes. Great scenery.

In closing, the movie is all around brilliant. Just try and ignore the ending.

title: More Like "Throw Away"
review: I was so excited to see this movie!  Generally speaking I am not the biggest fan of Tom Hanks, but was curious to see whether he could be redeemed in my eyes.  Enough said, I think he did a fabulous job of a boring movie.  Yes, boring.  The best part was the end, but unfortunately didn't turn out the way we had hoped.  After listening to the audience "ooh, ahh and cringe" I felt completely disappointed as the credits rolled.  The scenes were very predictable and lacking in originality.  Sorry....and thank god it was free.

title: Excellent Ending!
review: I had heard this was a pretty good movie with a weak ending.  On the contrary, I thought it was a very good movie with an excellent ending! The ending was not typical of Hollywood movie endings, so I enjoyed it! If you are looking for the Boy-meets-girl, boy-loses-girl, boy-wins-girl kind of plot so typical in todays movies, then you will not like the ending! If you can appreciate an ending you probably can't forsee - you'll like it!

title: I just can say: wow!
review:
Robert Zemeckis did it again! He never stops to impress me! Man, this guy is talented! What a great director.

And what a great film! I loved this movie. I laughed, I cried, and I enjoyed the film.

Certainly one of my favorite movies of the year. My second favorite, because Erin Brockovich is still my fave.

But man, this film was great. Very intelligent, with great acting, funny stuff, and lots of drama.

I loved Wilson! The interaction between Tom Hanks and Wilson was perfect. I cried when he got lost. I cried a lot! And I still can't believe it. I cried for a volleyball!!!

The ending of the film wasn't bad! It was great!!! The wings, all the symbolism. Everything! I rate this film with 10 stars.

Oh, and the music! Even though most of the film passed out with no music, the moments with music were great! I don't know yet who was the composer for this film, but he did his best! And excellent job.

What else? I don't know what else to say... Oh, I kept crying even when the film was already finished. I was walking with my mom to the car, and I was crying.

One more thing, the scene of the airplane crash was great! Wicked, horrible, terrific! Arrrggghhh, I loved this film!

One of the years best. I hope it gets nominated for the Oscars. I guess we'll have to wait and see.

title: Watchable, yet incredibly flawed
review: First off, I will agree with anyone who says the performance by Tom Hanks (And most any other actor or actress in this movie) was quite astounding. However, I feel this movie's problems are "What Lies Beneath" (To steal the title from Zemeckis' other film this year). Usually, I am the last person to say a movie is "boring"; oftentimes, my favorite movies are those with a 3-hour+ running time. At times, however, this movie, to be blunt, is BORING. The reason for this is because all the island scenes are strung together one after another; if the movie were to show one or two island scenes and then a scene of what was going on back home (Say, his friends' and families' reactions to the crash or his funeral), and so on, the pacing wouldn't have suffered so greatly. Second, on this island he has food, water, shelter, and so on. So why is he unhappy? Easy - No human contact. This is where Wilson the volleyball's role was so pivotal. Yet everyone in the auditorium, including myself, could not stop laughing. The movie failed on all counts to show Mr. Hanks' character's grief. I kept drawing parallels between the last 45 minutes of this film and David Croenberg's "The Dead Zone". Both feature a character who has been removed from society for a number of years and then is thrown back in, only to find that everything has changed. The movie could've succeeded here. It could've shown in detail what had changed, it could've further allowed Tom Hanks and Helen Hunt to show off their acting chops, it could've shown how the characters dealt with these changes, it could've been a better movie. In 1998's "The Thin Red Line", Terrence Malick proved to be quite a visionary director by showing silence and serenity and how it can get to a person. This probably would've made him the better director for "Cast Away". Alas, we'll never know. All in all, this isn't a bad movie so much as it is a disappointment. It's nice that Tom Hanks and Robert Zemeckis can make exceptionally good movies; it's just a shame this isn't one of them. ***

title: One of The Best Movies and Script I´ve ever seen!!!
review:
At the beginning of the movie, I thought the picture was just going to be another version of Daniel Defoe´s book Robinson Crusoe, but let me tell you that with Tom Hanks and Helen Hunt in the cast, you can feel the movie. When you see Tom Hanks trying to make fire, you notice how we sometimes do not appreciate life as we should, they have to take things away from us to really learn that we only live once.

Something amazing and that you will probably notice is how Tom Hanks really "workout" to be able to film the second part of the movie, something similar when he did "Philadelphia" with Denzel Washington.

I truly recommend this movie, when I was sitting at the theatre I wanted the story to never end, maybe because I was wishing the end was different, but I guess that´s what makes this movie one of the best.

Rubens (RAPL)

title: If it weren't for Hanks, this film would have drowned.
review:
Tom Hanks gives a VERY good performance in this film and I was never bored. The cinematography of the island, and the shots at end (which are symoblic to the story) are great and Hanks' acting talent is unreal. I don't know how he does it, here's a guy who was basicaly a stand up comedian and a television actor, until Big hit the screen and then he ended up in great roles in films like Phillidelphia and Forest Gump. He is the key in this film, if they got some other actor that didn't work this film would have been terrible.

This being said, the film has constant 'What would you do scenarios?', throughout the entire movie, and I am not always crazy about that. The biggest flaw I think with this film is that the trailer GIVES away the fact that Hanks gets off the island, in short the trailer TELLS you the entire movie. This is stupid, and the director said he did this deliberatly. Second... Hanks' return to the real world I think is VERY unrealistic and RUSHED through and perhaps even somewhat unnecessary. Basicaly he ends up back and there is literally a short scene where he is having a welcoming party with his office colleagues. They all come up to him and say things like 'Well we see you back at the office tomorrow regarding meeting ...", "Hey how about we shoot a round of golf, I am teeing off tommorow at 8", no no no... How about...

"Let's spend 1 year in psychotherapy, to figure out how to live again after not interacting with humans for 4+ years" This would be more the norm... and more realistic.



***POSSIBLE SPOILER DON'T READ IF YOU WANT TO SEE FILM ***



And thirdly, the meeting with the 'other husband' was done VERY badly, meaning it wasn't acted out or handled well. That's my take.



*** END SPOILER ***

This being said it is NOT a perfect film, it is NOT deserving of Best Picture, it is NOT deserving of Hanks WINNING Best Actor, but it does deserve a nomination but I don't think he should win not because his performance is bad, but because I think that other actors in films I have seen this year did better. Hanks did a fantastic job.

This movie I think is more of a spiritual, psychological awakening movie, than a tearjerking sappy love story film. Even with all this I did enjoy the film, and was never bored through it's 2 1/2+ hour run time.

Rating 7 out of 10

title: Not bad at all
review:
(Spoilers)

With very mixed reviews, "Cast Away" is a good and entertaining film, but it is not very thorough and it is somewhat flawed in the timeline department. I was actually very satisfied with the film - I had expected nothing more, and nothing less, so for once, my expectations were met almost exactly.

So what's wrong with this film? In hindsight, I can easily spot the flaws, but sitting in the theater I didn't mind them much. First and foremost, that which most negative reviews and comments focus on, is the 4-year leap. We get to see Noland surviving, adapting and realizing that he will not be found. Suddenly, the action jumps 4 years ahead, to the point where Noland finally gets a chance to leave. It wasn't very frustrating to me - Zemeckis and his crew obviously wanted to focus on the difference between Noland the survivor and Noland the Robinson. I find the stark contrast rather refreshing - because seriously: what should they have filled the intervening time with? More injuries? More reinventing the primitive tools of the caveman? I don't think so. It would have lengthened a film that in the end is not about the life of a Robinson, but about adaptability, strength and resolve. And to that end, the abrupt jump in time is not only acceptable, but necessary.

What I do think is a great flaw, and the only one that actually bothered me while watching, was the carefree way with which the movie deals with his homecoming. Sadly overlooked, the reactions of people around him and the massive amount of attention that he undoubtedly would receive, would have been valuable to the movie in terms of entertainment and clarification: just how did the world go on without him? Then again, the focus is not the world, but Noland. It's his sentiments, his life that has altered so profoundly, and the gap in time between his rescue and meeting with his former girlfriend is also a gap that is functional: how mindblowing mustn't it be to be rescued after 4 years alone on a tiny island with just a volleyball to talk to? How blank would his mind get after finally being brought back to civilization? The 4 weeks after his rescue would be filled with a weak, sleepy Noland without much to say or do. What Zemeckis could have added without much effort, is a sort of media commentary on Noland's story. The 4-week gap feels too much like a loss.

Zemeckis has an eye for human emotions and facial expressions that say more than words and music would. We get to see Hanks perform stunningly (as usual), regardless if he is a crowd-pleaser or not, and his time on the island is void of music and almost void of words. The film is superbly shot, some sequences almost taking the breath away. Some details weight heavily on the viewer - the removal of a bad tooth by way of an ice skating shoe that had the entire audience cringing in their seats, and the realistic and frightening scene where he tries to escape with the rubber raft and injures himself.

All in all, I think the negative reviews on this film are unfair and inconsiderate. I would like to know what should have been done instead. I just have a hard time seeing this film made different without losing focus: Noland and his life before, during and after his stay as a Robinson.

title: Incredible!
review: I thought Cast Away was simply incredible. What I liked most about this movie was the way it handled the situation and its cinematography. First, I believe if someone were to be stranded, there situation would be played out similar to Chuck's. No pirates, natives, snakes, buddies, abundant food supplies, and other plot devices every other movie of this genre uses. It is a man alone on a small island left to himself (and a volleyball). Hanks played this part so convincingly, I felt as if his character was always just teetering on the edge of insanity. Myself and others I saw this movie with felt real sorrow when Chuck loses Wilson. I felt this movie had a very strong ending. I believe it ended at the right point. We see how Chuck adjusts, but what he decides to do with his life is left up the the viewers imagination. I also believed the cinematography was spectacular. Granted, anything filmed in the South Pacific will look beautiful, the filming in this movie captures the feeling of being on the tiny island with Chuck. Four stars!

title: Above Average
review: This is about a fed-ex guy who crashes on a plane on a remote island. He survives off of things he finds on the beach , and then he starts sailing until he finds a ship.  Parts on the island can get boring after a while. The ending is a slight dissappointment. Rated PG-13 for , Violence/Language.

title: One of the best films of the year.
review:
Tom Hanks and Robert Zemeckis take you on a journey that you'll not soon forget. When we first meet Hanks' character, he's a time obsessed FedEx employee who lives by the clock. His entire life has to be scheduled at least a week in advance. Then, one fateful evening he departs on a plane that crashes into the Pacific. After surviving the crash, Chuck is washed ashore on an island in the middle of nowhere. Now, he has nothing but time on his hands. Slowly but surely, Chuck begins to reawaken primal insticnts that have layed dormant in him, and through this, we see just how resourseful, and resiliant humans can be. To their credit, Zemeckis and Hanks never resort to anything that would be found on Gilligan's Island. No pirates, no apes, no nothing in fact. All that is on island is Hanks, and whatever has washed ashore. Since humans are a social animal, the need for communication is essential, and one of the best relationships developed in the film is between Chuck and Wilson. Through Wilson, Chuck is able to express his concerns, his fears, his hopes and this allows him a shred of sanity.

Once again, Robert Zemeckis shows hi s mastery at the art of storytelling. He makes good use of the visual effects to propel the story forward, and the effects never take center stage. Even during the very realistic plane crash. The effects are there to help the story, they are not the story. Tom Hanks shows that he's one of the best actors working today. His weight loss for the film has been duly noted in many papers and periodicals but to see him go from a thick, bear like man to a skeletal frame with a scraggly beard is quite shock. He gives his all for his performance, and there are scenes on and off the island that contain only Hanks, and these scenes are heartbreaking.

Some may complain that the running time is too long, that the film starts to slow down once Hanks is on the island. Well, that's the point. We begin to feel what he's going through. With nothing but time on your hands, and no way to measure it, time seems to stand still.

Cast Away is one of the better films this season, and one of the best films of the year. Thanks in part to the performance of Tom Hanks and the masterful direction of Robert Zemeckis.

title: Triumph of the human spirit...howzat?
review:
CAST AWAY has gotten much praise as a sort of existential

blockbuster: Tom Hanks, a stick, a volleyball and a crab for a

whole hour! J. Hoberman has memorably described as the

"bleakest vision of human existence in studio filmmaking since

Douglas Sirk's IMITATION OF LIFE."

Beg to differ. The key that winds this baby up is the theme that

unites most high-period Tom Hanks movies: the American can-do

spirit. Like the guy using a sock and a ballpoint pen to fix a

spaceship in APOLLO THIRTEEN, like the guy firing a pistol feebly

at a Panzer tank in SAVING PRIVATE RYAN, Hanks' Chuck Noland,

FedEx work and late-twentieth-century guy extraordinaire, doesn't

so much look into the abyss as kick its butt using technology and a

little bit of Yankee elbow grease. Hanks, a fan of 2001, seems to

have completely mislearned its lessons: no major commercial

film artist, not even James Cameron, seems so enraptured by the

transcendent power of technos.

The director, Robert Zemeckis, lays it on thick at the beginning:

Chuck is a time-is-money type-A geek who sits with his fiancee

(Helen Hunt) and plots out quality time with her as they both peer

into identical datebooks. (Had the movie not been inexplicably set

in 1995, they could zap their Palm Pilots at each other.) Then,

marooned on a desert island...well, you'd think he'd learn

something about stopping to smell the roses. Or his laid-on-thick

emotional blockedness. Or something, other than how to rub two

sticks together. But, as if they studied Bresson and David Mamet,

Hanks and Zemeckis have no time for sticky feelings. It's

procedure, the how-to, that excites them. And though it must have

seemed terribly daring to spend so much time with one guy

onscreen, a static camera, and no music or dialogue, this stuff is

by far the most engaging in the movie.

The movie gets inspirational in its last movements, a tribute to

never giving up, or not letting go of your dream, or love-will-show-the-way, or some other development-world cliche.

The last moments of the movie are staggering in their inadequacy.

The filmmakers seem to have eschewed every possible cornball

ending, every chance for cheap uplift...and then they replace it with

nothing at all. The movie doesn't so much end as stop, as if the

screenwriter, puzzled and disgusted, threw his typewriter across

the room.

The level of drama isn't helped much by the casting of Helen Hunt

as Chuck's beloved. Is there a more unsympathetic major female

star in movies today? Hunt right now has the number one and two

movies in America. What are people seeing that I'm missing? And

does Hanks realize how much of this performance, which some

are touting as among the greatest of all time, is a carbon copy of

his work in a little number called JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO?

title: Great Movie!
review: Yet another spectacular performance by our hero Tom Hanks. This movie makes you realize how valuable life really is. This movie is about a Fedex employee who is the only survivor of a plane crash. He is stuck on an island for 4 years without anybody except Wilson, the volleyball. This movie is great, but there are a few scenes that might be disturbing to younger audiences.

title: Missed Opportunities
review:
DANGER!!! SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!

It is well known that Tom Hanks took 6 months off to lose the weight needed to make the "4 years later..." transition. One would think during that time, somebody could have contemplated a better resolution... "Anybody?!!". Someone wrote here before me, the lack of transition between the rescue and the return to the real world was a disappointment. I agree. There seems to be a hole in the story that is circumvented by "4 weeks later..." Those 4 weeks could have been alot more intriguing than the 3rd act we're given.

DANGER!!! SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!

For instance, I wanted to see Hanks being rescued. He wakes up to a ship and then he's on a plane "4 weeks later". It would have been alot more interesting to explore his view from nothingness-to-everything during this time. There would be press junkets and a book deal somewhere in the making. Instead, he returns to his job at Fed-Ex and we get a tacked-on ending to resolve a nowhere relationship. It would have been more satisfying for Hanks to return to the Island, possibly with the family of the Fed-Ex worker he buried. Zemeckis was overflowing with ideas for Forrest Gump. Here, it is like he runs out of gas.

Be forewarned, if you are sensitive to a fidgety audience, wait for the video. There is about an hour of near silence that can be deafening in a theater.

I can't dismiss the film as a whole. The plane crash is amazing and the central part of Hanks on the Island is the saving grace. Very thought provoking. What would you do if you just survived an impossible situation only to find that that was the easy part? Great premise, great acting, poor follow-thru. Too bad somebody didn't step forward and go the final mile.

7 out of 10

title: Put a gun against my head. Pull the trigger, now I'm dead...
review:
Here's a suggestion for Bob Zemekis: END YOUR MOVIE. Two and a half

hours and all I get is some idiot looking at a road! Man, he should have

gone back to that house with that hot chick! Okay, something else. Tom

Hanks' Jeep Cherokee is a 98, or later, edition car. He leaves on his

quest in 95. What's up with that. You spend millions of dollars and

take a year's break in shooting, but you can't get a simple (and

pivitol) prop correct. That car thing negates his adventure's timeline.

To me, he just fell down some stairs and dreamed his little adventure.

The acting is good, but who cares. Tom Hanks is so consistant that you

almost don't care how good his acting is. Saying that Tom Hanks is not

a good actor is like saying that The Godfather is a bad movie: it's not

true. Acting good. Movie d

title: Slightly shallow, but a good ride.
review:
This is a GREAT film. Being that the majority of films of 2000 were not that great, this is a shoe-in for multiple Oscar nominations.

Tom Hanks gives a great performance, really making us feel as though we're there with him... as though our fates are entwined with his. His ability for acting shines in this role.

The greater part of the movie rests in mostly silence, as we watch Hanks' character, Chuck, struggling to live on the tiny island which has become his prison. What's interesting about this is that it rips away all the advances and advantages we as a human race have gained, leaving Chuck to learn all over again how to survive.

Rarely have I been actually hurt when I've seen a character on screen experience pain. One scene in particular which makes the audience cry out is when Chuck loses Walter. I doubt there was one person in the theater that wasn't hurt... wasn't hoping against hope that Hanks would get him back, and was almost in tears when he didn't.

Granted, the plot of this film is not complex, and does not require much thought, but that's not a bad thing. Tom Hanks' acting ability turns what could have been a mediocre role into one of depth, making the viewer sympathise with every hardship he must endure.

One thing I've heard many times over is how bad the ending is. Why? Because it's not 'happily ever after?' It is NOT a warm and cozy ending... it's not made to make us feel good inside. It's realistic. And to those who scoff and Hanks' sadness, you've failed to really FEEL his character. Put yourself in his shoes. How would you feel?

Want a funny movie? See "Dude Where's My Car?" Want a movie with a happy ending? See "Gladiator." Want an emotional movie to envelop you and truly tie your feelings into knots? See this one.

You will not be disappointed.

title: A stellar performance
review: If Tom Hanks does not get an Oscar for his performance, I will be completely shocked. This film has so much going for it, the cinematography (breathtaking), the silent struggles of Hanks on the island, marking off the days in solitude, his efforts to survive and his deliberations about not wanting to, Tom Hanks conveys so much with expression and gesture and minimal dialogue.  I was completely caught up. The only feeling of letdown was in the ending, it appeared as if the writer did not know where to take it.  The 4 years away must have spiritually transformed and indelibly changed Tom Hanks, but there is no accommodation for this.  This is unfortunate, as an otherwise stunning movie left me feeling ripped off. I gave it 8 out of 10 for the 90% that was incredible.

title: There is no justice...
review: There is no justice in Hollywood if this film doesn't receive academy award noms for actor, director and picture (to say the least). If you want to see a film that will make you think - this is the film for you. I was spellbound by it and think I left the theater with something from this movie. A better understanding of the morals of life.

title: This is an excellent film!
review: In my opinion, this was actually a `film', rather than a `movie'.  I liked it anyway.  To me, a "film" is a movie where we are supposed to think about things.  A "movie" is simply meant to entertain.  In this film, we are taken into the world of Chuck Noland, a FedEx employee.  We learn that he is his job.  Time is his enemy.  He loves his girlfriend Kelly, but to be together, they must compare planners.  Then, his world changes drastically.  He attempts to do things in his usual manner, very quickly.  Time teaches him patience.  We don't learn about Chuck through dialog as much as we do through the lens.  There are scenes in the movie where we feel what the characters in the movie must be feeling, simply by seeing endless ocean and endless prairie.  We also see the might of nature in stunning storm tossed seas and powerful winds.  If you are patient, Chuck will tell you why he survived and then you will learn if he will survive.  If I say anything more, it would spoil it for you.  This movie is 2 and a half hours long, but it doesn't feel like a long movie.  I honestly didn't notice the time passing.  I do recommend this movie, whether you expect a movie to challenge your thinking or are someone that likes to be entertained.  If you are like me, you are probably both.

title: Just Excellent
review: This is just a good (!) movie. Good pace, perfect focus on characters, perfect photography. It is really interesting to notice that viewer reviews are VERY different from each other, and focus on different aspects of the movie. Clearly this movie contains MUCH more that it appears... ;-) I did not like the Fed-Ex commercial, though Conclusion: see it, and possibly see it again

title: Gripping, Excellent, yet Confusing
review: This movie was fantastic. Great special effects, and each island scene couldn't have been better. The plane crash scene was edge-of-your seat directing. Bob Zemeckis can make a movie very well. However, you are left with a bittersweet taste at the end as to whether or not (SPOILER HERE) Chuck gets the girl or not. Zemeckis kind of leaves the audience hanging here, which provides you with a kind of "Huh?" thought in your head as you walk out of the theater. Many of Zemeckis' films leave you with a lack of catharsis at the end of the film, such as Back to the Future III. Otherwise, the film was excellent. However the trailer is misleading and hints that Chuck and his girl live happily ever after. Anyway, you should see this movie, and decide for yourself what you think happened. Enjoy.

title: It's about DIVORCE
review:
A remarkable film, truly inspired and amazingly executed. This is no "teenager" movie! You have to be wise enough to appreciate life, love and loss... in short you must have LIVED to understand it. Most of the viewing crowd (young and old) hasn't the wisdom and will not understand even 10% of this movie, all they can get out of it is the superficial.

If you didn't understand The Green Mile in all of it's deliciously complicated splendor, you will fail to undertstand Cast Away... yes, I mean "Cast Away", not "Castaway". But for those of you who have gone through the pain of IMMEASURABLE LOSS, you WILL understand.

I said it's about divorce, because that is the journey of loss I related to. Some of the more obvious symbology that alludes to this thesis are the divorce certificate in the FedEx box (his job leads to a divorce), the dead pilot's family picture (there is no wife in the photo), the island represents his despair and loneliness at being "cast away" by his wife, but at the same time the island is a sanctuary which allows him to experience and reveal his true "self". Further, the island (lonliness and separation) feeds, protects and cares for him over time so he can grow strong to meet the challenge of the waves (change/journey). Finally, the raft represents the promise of a new life, the volleyball the old self, the paddles represent letting go and accepting God/Fate/reality, and the whale is the confidence that there is a spirit/guide/guardian/angel watching over us (all we have to do is listen).

The movie is beautifully made and has a beautiful message... SURVIVING LOSS. Whether that loss is the loss of a loved one because of divorce or through physical death, this movie is about surviving the greatests depths of despair, and surviving our inner psychological worlds ... not our physical worlds.

Those of you who have, will know what I mean.

John

title: such wonders
review:
In many ways, Cast Away reminds me very much of another very good Robert Zemeckis film, Contact. Both of them had endings that were somewhat disappointing (as one person I heard said it about Contact "I waited three hours to see the aliens and they're her freaking father?"). Cast Away's ultimate conclusion was even more ambiguous and troubling, but that does not keep it from being an enthralling and interesting film and one of the ten best movies of the year, just as Contact was enthralling and interesting and one of the ten best movies of its year.

In short, Hanks plays Chuck Noland, a gung-ho Fedex supervisor/trouble shooter/slave driver who travels the world licking troubled Fedex centers into shape. He loves Kelly Frears (Helen Hunt), a Ph.D student close to finishing her dissertation. On Christmas Eve, and on the eve he was to propose marriage, he is sent on a flight to Asia. The plane goes off course and then down in an incredibly gripping sequence. Noland (No-land - even his name has meaning in this film) is the only survivor and he washes ashore onto an isolated rock in the middle of the Pacific with nothing to survive with. He salvages his raft (the survival kit and flares went down with the plane), and some Fedex packages that wash ashore, and sets up camp.

The bulk of the film is made up of Hank's attempts to survive on the island, primarily in two episodes - how he acclimatizes and learns to survive, and then four years later, when he at last has a chance to get off the island. The script is really remarkably well done, considering that Hanks has no one to speak to for the bulk of the film (although he does create a 'friend' out of a volleyball with whom he converses). The Fedex packages that wash ashore at first seem worse than useless, but their uses are very clever and hidden. Noland does all of the things you think of doing yourself, often at the same time you are reaching the same conclusions, although I have to say he's many times more resourceful than I - I would have died on that island. The drama of surviving, and Hanks' abilities as an actor to keep everything human, are engrossing. Noland's island is a forbidding spit of sand and rock way out somewhere, and there is no man Friday to help this Robinson Crusoe. Every problem he has, from making fire to dealing with a rotting tooth with no anesthetic and no tools, are dealt with in a straightforward and realistic fashion.

Zemeckis's direction is outstanding. The crash scene is tense, frightening and incredibly well done (so well done it deserves mention more than once). Zemeckis (and his cinematographer) strand Hanks on an island that they show is both amazingly beautiful and also barren and desolate. Hanks' buddy, Wilson the volleyball, is handled so well by the director (and the script) that Hanks' constant banter with it makes you begin to understand how he relies on the volleyball to keep his sanity while at the same time imparting the feeling that the ball really is talking back somehow.

Noland's escape from the island is also very well done, and this should be no spoiler to anyone who has seen a commercial for the film that gives this part away. The bittersweet reunification with Hunt's Frears is effective, and Hanks has a wonderful speech at the close of the film that encapsulates the film's theme, about the powerlessness and hopelessness we sometimes feel in life and the importance of tides. Then it maybe goes on a little too long, and leaves with a totally ambiguous and unfulfilling ending. Oh well. I'll only have to watch this one nine more times before I'm sick of it. Nine out of ten. Laughing Lion says go check it out.

title: Interesting Movie
review: This movie has many different points which can relate to normal people. The way Tom Hanks acted in it is remarkable. He depicted exactly how someone would respond to the environment alone. I too would have probably started talking to myself and making up friends. The one thing I don't understand about this movie is how it ended, Tom Hanks was just standing in the middle of the road staring off into nowhere. Other than that it was a decent movie, I think Tom Hanks deserves an Academy Award nomination for this role.

title: Excellent
review: I love this movie!!! It was wierd at the beginning, it seemed like a different story. It was suspenceful, funny, sad, and adventureous. Even though there were only two main characters (Tom Hanks and Wilson) it stayed interesting and funny. I will definitely add this to my movie collection.

title: Infomercial
review:
OK, so does anyone know how much FedEx payed to have their name plastered throughout this movie? I can only think of a few scenes in the entire movie where their name wasn't on the screen. That got very annoying.

The movie itself was just excruciatingly boring. You could have easily trimmed 40 minutes off of it. Just stay home and watch Forrest Gump on TV and wait for a FedEx commercial.

title: we are now paying the price for "survivor"
review:
i havent even seen "castaway" yet, but any film where a two-time oscar winner talks to a volleyball has to be avoided. also, are there any films out currently that dont feature helen hunt?? geezus...tom hanks should of made "bachelor party 2" instead

final verdict - 1 out of 10 (and thats just for the teaser trailer)

title: A good film. Worth the journey
review:
I like Tom Hanks, I like him in this film. I usually enjoy Zemeckis films, I enjoyed this film a lot.

The best part is indeed the "stranded on an island part". Hanks is no superman, just a reasonably intelligent guy who got lucky. Lucky to survive a "landing on water" (which for big jets is usually fatal) and lucky to be washed across the reef and onto an island. Lucky also to be able to survive significant puncture wounds that would kill most people through infection. You have to have a strong constitution to survive daily contact with a coral reef. It looks so peaceful and beautiful, but it is very dangerous (the book "Castaway" by Lucy Irvine is a good read and may well have been an inspiration to Hanks and company).

The boat escape from the island was pure drama, getting over the big wave was such a thrill.

Remainder of the film was not that interesting but I thought the ending was effective.

I gave it a 9 out of 10 stars and I would be glad to see it again.

title: Great acting, boring movie
review: This is really sad and disappointing, seeing Tom Hanks in a badly scripted and directed movie. The idea was good but it turned out to be a 2+ hours FedEx commercial with no story. The time gap is horrible, even a kid could think of something better than displaying "4 years later". At least it deserves the Oscar for best commercial advertising.

title: The intangibles make the film and Hanks' performance
review:
POSSIBLE SPOILERS

We are becoming increasingly hard-pressed to find a better actor in Hollywood today than Tom Hanks. Every movie of his is an event and a must-see, as was this one. When this film debuted around Christmas 2000, I wondered if this film would hold up to the Hanks tradition of late. He makes good choices of films to appear in, and doesn't half-*** anything (from Philadelphia through Forrest Gump through Saving Private Ryan through this year's Road to Perdition). This movie would not be the movie it is in my mind without Tom Hanks and his solo performance. And let's face it, that's what it is. I can't think of any other role where one actor was asked to hold for screen by himself for scene after scene after scene like he did in this film. What's remarkable about the situation is that he did it so well, and in my opinion, was robbed of the Best Actor award for 2000 by Russell Crowe's good but less demanding performance in Gladiator.

The movie begins in Russia, where Chuck Noland (Hanks) is working. He is a FedEx shipping supervisor whose life is ruled by, in a word, time. The clock is his enemy, his boss, his friend when necessary, and remains ever-present in his life. He is about to propose to his girlfriend, Kelly Frears (Helen Hunt), back home in Memphis, TN. Before New Year's, he finds out that he has to go on short notice to Malaysia, much to the displeasure of Kelly. He gives her the ring before he leaves, without much fanfare, and leaves for the plane. On the way, in a frighteningly scary and seemingly real plane crash, Chuck becomes the only survivor of an awful accident, and becomes marooned on a small, unoccupied island. There his personal odyssey begins.

At this point, the film becomes something else. It doesn't dissolve into typical Hollywood melodramatics and awful lamenting; instead, he struggles to survive through body and mind, at once staringly longingly into Kelly's face (through a small, now broken clock/family heirloom containing her picture), and at another instance using his will to find food and survive, with Kelly's face driving him. As time passes and it becomes clear that almost nobody knows this island exists, you can only imagine his man's internal musings about what life becomes, isolation, heartbreak, beauty, struggle, and so on. Being able to identify with Chuck Noland and be riveted by his predicament is to thoroughly enjoy the film; for those bored by an utter lack of dialogue for more than half the film will be disappointed, and I personally know many people who fall into the latter category. Noland's character is not the type to expound on his feelings, and at film's end, he hasn't changed drastically, but it is quite enough to feel for him, as I certainly did.

Robert Zemeckis's direction is chock-full of subtlety, and the better the film is for it, because scene after scene of over-the-top craziness, good or bad for the characters, doesn't fit the mood of the film (and Alan Silvestri's hauntingly spare score, for that matter).
