Themes abound throughout, such as the repetitive feelings about time and its absence on the island. Some say the ending is disappointing, but I disagree; it makes perfect sense for the film's tone.

Overall: see this for Hanks and his downright towering performance, and also intangibles of Chuck Noland's thoughts. Empathy is a huge bonus for the enjoyment of this film. 8/10

title: Good Movie but overhyped
review: First of all I want to spank to the people that promoted this movie. The preview featured music from Braveheart. Great, but please don't do it again. We all now that James Horner achieved his maximum in Braveheart but that doesnt mean that everybody has to use the music in all previews. Remember, Titanic also used Braveheart's music in the preview. I guess that because the music is so nice they'll get more people to see the movie. Anyway, for a movie that didnt promise too much, a castaway lost in his pacific island for two hours, I have to admit that Cast Away surprised me. I didnt find the movie boring at all because there are a lot of humor in it, and you get along with Tom Hanks role. But besides from that I don't think this movie is by far the best of the year. Its a good movie, but I don't think it could be better.

title: Very Engaging
review: "CastAway" was gripping from start to finish.  I was very drawn into the story and I really cared about what was to become of Tom Hanks' character. Hanks, by the way, was brilliant yet again and showed his fantastic talent even in a film with limited dialogue and interaction with other characters. The film direction and cinematography were also outstanding and the plane crash sequence was, well, very intense to say the least.  Overall it was a very good movie with an engaging and engrossing story, superb acting, and a great message to end the film. Check it out, it's worth it.

title: Sort of Tarzan meets Gilligan.
review: After four years alone on an island, you would think that the main character could make himself a more comfortable bed, an perhaps have painted at least a few more pictures on the wall of his cave.  Mostly impressive for the lead's performance and weight loss.

title: In a world that is tired of long movies, this could have been the exception.
review: Watching this film left me and my friends thinking that maybe the butcher accidently cut off some of the meat while he was trimming the fat.  Tom Hanks did great... but that is part of the problem.  I ended up wanting to know more about his four years.  Seems like the studio/filmmaker/whoever was a little too occupied with keeping the movie around 2 1/2 hours and not enough time giving us what we were hungering for.  Redeeming qualities? Well, let's just say Castaway features one of the best disaster sequences I have ever seen.   This movie would have worked much better as a 3 hour flick or a mini series... Strange for me to say, but that's how I feel.

title: Truly one of the best films of 2000.Tom Hanks best performance since "Philadelphia".
review: "Cast Away" is a wonderful film with an excellent performance by Tom Hanks that deserves to be recognized by the academy.I left the theater, not being able to forget how emotional the movie ran through me.At a full two hours and thirty five minutes,I was entertained by Tom Hanks' performance which made me feel the same kind of emotions that I had when I had seen "Philadelphia".Tom Hanks is a Fed-Ex delivery executive who happens to be in a plane that crashes into the ocean.He drifts onto an island where he is forced to spend four years on a deserted island.On that island,he must learn to survive and fight for his sanity.Tom Hanks has delivered some of the most incredible performances in his acting career and his second collaboration with director Robert Zemeckis is a real treat for fans of Tom Hanks and Robert Zemeckis.Tom Hanks is well supported by Academy Award winner Helen Hunt,whose performance should be recognized with another Academy Award nomination.And I mean should,because she deserves it.Even if she doese not win,she should be recognized by the academy.Director Robert Zemeckis brings the audience into a spectacular,beautiful world.Choosing the locations set on the islands and the ocean were a breathtaking experience.The cinematography and the score are among the film's best contributions."Cast Away",along with "Forrest Gump","The Hurricane" and "Saving Private Ryan" is a must see.Take the time to see "Cast Away" because you will walk out that theater feeling good inside yourself."Cast Away" is truly one of the best films of 2000 and Tom Hanks proves that he scores.My vote for this film:One of the best films of 2000.

title: Left a bad taste in my mouth
review: It would have been an ok.  I would have enjoyed it more had it not been for all that FedEx product placement.  It was by far the worst I have ever seen. It made me so upset I almost left the theatre.  We shouldn't have to pay for a film with that much advertising. Secondly, the theatrical trailer showed the whole dang film, beginning, middle and unfortunately the end. And my last bitter comment was the "four years later" that came up.  I felt robbed when that came on screen.  What happened?  I wanted to see his interaction once he is rescued.  Oh well, guess it's not my movie.

title: good film, should have been set in the 60s
review: My only real complaint about Cast Away is that it is virtually impossible to get lost on a tropical island, WITH a life raft (since rafts nearly universally I think, in this modern day have emergency transmitters (EPRBs or something like that)  that can be picked up by satellite and your location gets sent to the coast guard).  The jets radio black out is also rather implausible. The lack of infection from a major injury in topical (bacteria infested) waters is also at least extremely lucky. One of the things I liked abou it is that its sort of just a story of a guy going through an amazing experience, just s slice of life, not major upheaval and resolution and etc etc, an amazing slice of  life due to the circumstances, but just a guy somehow managing to get thorugh it.  Could have been you or me.  That, in addtion to the excellent direction, on location etc. gives it a very realistic feel.  I think Philadelphia is still Hank's best work, but Cast Away is good.

title: It's c**p, and it'll be a huge Oscar contender
review:
Here's a great idea gone wrong...SPOILERS AHEAD, NOT THAT TRAILER DIDN'T SPOIL EVERYTHING ANYWAY

It begins by saturating us with the fact that Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks) lives his life on a strict schedule. In a future BATMAN film, they would set-up the Clock King's pre-menacing days similarly. After the first three lines of dialogue were out of Hanks' mouth, I had the entire exposition mapped out in my head. I was half-expecting that Hanks would -- after the plane crash -- return to his wife (Helen Hunt) as a snowman. I should note that as a JACK FROST reference only because I'm not confident that many of you have seen it (obviously, if you haven't, don't).

So after the crash, Hanks floats to the island where we spend a good chunk of the movie alone with him. Mostly good stuff here, especially when dealing with basic survival. I was able to completely forget that Hanks was just an actor surrounded by a film crew. The lack of music and the sustained sequences let you inside Chuck Noland's skin. It is therefore a dreadful mistake on the part of the filmmakers to pull us out of that skin when we are starting to identify with it. "Four years later," says the title card. I would have liked 15 or 20 more minutes on the island, or enough to properly transition Chuck Noland from a baffled plane crash survivor to a suicide-contemplating loon who talks to volleyballs. And if they showed that damn stopwatch with Helen Hunt's picture one more time, I'd be overcome by nausea. It was almost as sappy as the use of the compass in Zemeckis' CONTACT. Same syrupy significance.

Now, if you've been watching this guy rub sticks together for an hour, wouldn't it be interesting to see his rescue and his potentially jarring re-introduction to civilisation? Let's face it, as horrible as the entire situation would be, it'd almost be worth being stranded to be rescued. It'd be like being carried off home plate after hitting the game-winning home run in Game 7 of the World Series. What a missed opportunity to skip this emotional rollercoaster and instead plunk down another title card: "One month later." Well, I want to know what that month was like. Throw in the four years I missed and I'd be even happier.

All of the events shown after Hanks' arrival home are uninteresting. I really didn't want to know about any of it. Zemeckis once again chose sentimentality over imagination. We get a long kiss in a rainstorm and a cheesy "guardian angel/freedom" symbol that dumps more sugar on the pile that the pocket-watch started. There is no transition from rescued Hanks to recovering Hanks. If you started watching the film from the "One month later" title card, you'd barely think that this man spent over four years on a deserted island.

Some great sequences at least make this entertaining frustration. Less c**p, more good stuff, and smoother transitions; that would have resulted in a better film. As Hanks would say in the similarly-flawed FORREST GUMP, "That's all I have to say about that."

Grade: C

title: Great Hanks Movie
review: WOW SPOILER What a great job by Tom Hanks to pull off a whole movie without saying anything for 30 min.  Amazing.  The cinematography is wonderful and the film is intriguing even without dialect. The only drawback to the film was the ending.  Boring and endless.  Awe. She thought he was dead and she still loves him.  Now he's back and she's married.  boo-hoo  The final three minutes did see a very large improvement to rescue the film. Overall I like the story and acting, so I give it 4 stars out of 5.

title: Eating some peanut butter??
review:
SPOILER ALERT!!!

Ok...I saw Cast Away and really enjoyed the film. I've seen a lot of comments suggesting that the end of the movie was tacked on and, basically, not finished. This didn't really bother me as I sometimes like to come to my own conclusions.

The one aspect where I did wish the movie expanded was when he was actually rescued and reunited with civilization. What did he do when they brought him up on the cargo ship? Did he freak out when he saw people, having been out of practice "socializing" for four years? What food did he ask for? Did he remember how to take a shower and shave? I would have liked to see the movie expanded here, as I'm sure Tom Hanks would have portrayed the character very sensitively and unsure as to how to be civilized again.

title: Does he get the girl?
review:
I don't know if he gets the girl or not at the end, but contrary to someone else's earlier posting, Hanks most certainly at least pursues the opportunity with Lari White character at the end. The earlier poster wrote:

"He was at the last looking down a different road, the one toward California. " SPOILER ALERT That is incorrect. Hanks stepped out from his jeep into the middle of the intersection. He looked forward, then to the left and right, and finally turned back around and faced up in the direction of his jeep which is the direction toward the woman's ranch. His hint of a smile combined with other factors mentioned by other commenters clearly implies that Hanks goes back to pursue this new opportunity. When you couple that with the last words of the previous scene where Hanks talks about how his will to live changed with the port a potty shell which "washed up on the beach" and that life is about seeing what washes up next it becomes clear to me that Lari White becomes Hanks's next opportunity which "washes up on the beach."

As far as I'm concerned, this is a great ending. I can't stand Helen Hunt and the only reason I was able to go see this otherwise outstanding film was the foreknowledge that Hunt occupies very few minutes on the screen.

title: I loved it ,I was a little disappointed on how it ended
review: I liked it it was very good.It showed you never know when something can happen and totally change your life.Tom Hanks did a super job.I was a little disappointed on how it ended ,however it was a good movie and I would absolutely recommend it

title: Wilson for Best Supporting Actor
review:
I want Wilson to be nominated for Best Supporting actor! A supporting actor is there to give depth and help reflect main actors and that is what Wilson does.

Also, this is by far the best Hanks has done in a film. In Philadelphia and Forrest Gump his characters did not have to change much in the way of personality but here... wow!

title: nearly hits the mark
review: For a film that features basically one actor for an hour and a half, this delivers pretty well.  Hanks is some sort of air courier whose plane crashes in the middle of the ocean.  He manages to find an island and do the old "live off the land" thing for awhile.  One of two things I didn't go for was the length of time he supposedly spends marooned.  Others have spoiled it but I will leave it to you in finding out, it just seemed too unreal.  I feel he would've lost his mind after just a few months if he didn't die from the elements first.  Hanks really manages to hold the film together pretty well, as they interject a good amount of comic moments.  The filming style is a bit odd, as Bob Z.  uses a sort of documentary style, using no music and shooting Hanks work activities mostly in close-up.  It's all well photographed, especially a very dramatic plane crash.  But that other thing I didn't like about the film makes a real difference: the totally dissatisfying ending.  After about 90 minutes on the island, the screenplay only dedicates about 15 minutes to Hanks homecoming (yes, that could be considered spoiling, but you probably saw it in the previews anyway).  Not enough of his return to society was explored, and things close out with a dull stare into the camera that doesn't resolve anything.  Also look out for shameless plugs for "Federal Express" and Wilson volleyballs, which Hanks actually befriends(!).  That could've done with a little trimming as well, his wacked out love for the ball.  I know he's lonely and needed a "companion", but they should've said enough already with the tears after he loses his buddy.  But I would suggest you go for the survival element, which totally shocked me with its pace.  I usually check my watch a few times during a film but was amazed to see it was the 2 hour mark when I first did it with this movie.  Zemeckis directed the most excellently paced movie ever (in my opinion), "Back to the Future", and he doesn't fail here, keeping things going with engrossing vignettes of what Hanks goes thru.  The meager other cast members are good, like barely seen Hunt, who found herself in big holiday movies two weeks in a row.  But look out for that ending, which sinks "Cast Away" from being great (couldn't resist).

title: Time well spent
review:
Very good film, not great. I always enjoy Tom Hanks' performance even if he is playing himself on Letterman. This film was no exception. It didn't wimp out at the end with a storybook close and I appreciated that. Could it have been better. Yeah sure but then wasn't it great that there were no dinosaurs or pirates on the island!!

For a long film with limited dialogue it didn't drag for me and was a lot more interesting and fun that Survivor.

title: Mr. Wilson (sorta spoiler)
review: I just wish at the end of the movie they'd have had Tom Hanks out on a beach, looking out, reflecting on everything that has happened, and have Mr. Wilson wash up on shore.  The movie was great though.  Those of you looking for crazy special effects stay home.

title: Overall very satisfied with this movie
review: Wow...what a rush!  Can you imagine falling from 30,000 feet to the earth? The crash scene was really intense and Hank's interpretation of the utter helplessness felt by his character was superb.  It's amazing how one's mind fixates on something important (gold watch) and one is willing to risk life and limb to obtain this object! It still amazes me how an actor can sacrifice so much while making a film. Hanks had to have lost 30 pounds or more to portray the nearly starved crazy 'Gilligan'. It was a little depressing towards the end when he gets rescued only to find that...well...see for yourself. Overall a very good movie and I would enjoy seeing it again!

title: Amazing! (Some spoilers)
review:
I went into this movie just so i would have something to do for a few hours, but came out amazed! Many people misunderstand the whole movie, saying it didn't have enough action or the four years with Tom Hanks on the island was too long. I myself think that the entire movie was well balanced and well done.

The movie showed extremely well how you would try to survive on an island by yourself. It showed the challenge of hunting your food, creating fire so you could cook you food, and mainly STAYING SANE! The one thing that kept Tom Hanks' character sane (or at least some what sane, he does talk to a vollyball) is Helen Hunt's character, but we never really got to know her, because later Hanks finds out(when he gets back) that being with her again, is not possible. Sort of ironic.

Many people thought the ending was horrible, but i think it shows well the many choices that Hanks had to face. By puting him in the middle of the intersection, he must go one way, and that direction may change his life. The women that came and told him what there was each direction, was not a "replacement" for Helen Hunt, but merely another choice, and kind of a guide by telling him what each road lead to.

In conclusion this movie was very risky, because of the lack of dialogue and action (after all he is on an island for four years by himself) but Tom Hanks was able the pull it off and give and excellent performance. I could not have chosen a better movie to watch when i need something to do. I'll be sure to get this one on DVD when it comes out! GO WATCH IT!

title: Great Hanks performance, but...
review: You've read the synopses, you know what the movie is about. Let's get to the meat... skip if you wish no spoilers. Tom Hanks did a fantastic job of creating a believable character. His acting was perfect for the role. Up until his eventual rescue the film is excellent. Sure, we could have seen more of his "decline" into more primitive processes, and it would have added to the movie. The roundabout way his suicide attempt is introduced in the movie is effective. The crash is harrowing. His discoveries on the island are phenomenal. His "transformation" into the lean, thousand-yard stare, almost-hopeless primate is wonderful (he seems almost neanderthal in his reaction to the porta-potty piece in the water... loved it). The movie _after_ the rescue missed its mark. Hanks discussion with his friend on the private plane had neither the stilted quality one might expect from someone whose sole partner for 4 years was a punctured volleyball, nor did it have the possibly clamouring quality of someone who is finally around a lost friend. I could expect either, but instead we are treated to a rather bland characterisation. In fact, all of the interactions with others (save the rather emotional monologue to the same friend later) have this detached quality that TO ME seems inappropriate somehow. This is almost painfully true in his interaction with his long-lost sweetie, played by Helen Hunt. My problem is I can't seem to be able to imagine any _real_ people, when placed in the same situation, who would act the way that both of them act. Even the "last chance" part towards the end didn't have that emotion that one would expect in the situation. Anyway, I enjoyed the film, but am still mildly disappointed with the points above. I will still, however, probably buy it when it comes out on DVD. Go figure.

title: Disappointing
review: I am sorry to say, especially with all the hype thrown at this film, that I did not like this film.  Mainly the problem is the film tried to go somewhere, but left me hanging on where.  Most of the actions Hanks takes on the island the film doesnt fill us in on what he is trying to accomplish, and by the time you figure it out, he is on to his next action.  At the beginning they could have had him talk to himself filling us in on what he's trying to do.  It does get a little better when he talks to Wilson.  They just didn't fill in enough for the viewer, they left too much up to the viewer to figure out. And the ending once again, just leaves the viewer in the middle of nowhere trying to figure it out.  All in all, disappointing.

title: An introspective look at the thematic implications of Cast Away.
review:
I am feeling, well, melancholy isn't perhaps the right word, but close. Pensive? Contemplative? I have been in this state for nearly 5 days now, and this is my homage to that feeling--this is my way of capturing it, harnessing it. As thoughts flood into my head I desperately try to write them down as quickly as possible, but surely some will get washed away with the tide.

I have just returned from a movie that has altered, or re-affirmed my view of life and the world. It is my second time seeing Cast Away, and I am undoubtably changed. Not so much changed, but perhaps intensely more aware of what is important in life.

All my days equalling 22 years to this point, have told me one day I would "become," but as I'm growing to learn, you never finish "becoming"--as you learn more and more about life and the world you try things on for size and see how they fit you. It doesn't end--nobody taps you on the head with a magic wand one day and says "ok, you have 'become', now go and live." It is the living that fuels the becoming.

That said, there are definitely defining times or moments when one feels themselves "becoming" faster or closer to who they think they are. This was one such time for me, watching Tom Hanks live out on screen my dream.

I really battle with the idea of who I am. One day I think I know, the next it has changed without warning. Identity is so difficult because you can't have an objective opinion about yourself, yet only you know yourself well enough to determine your own identity. This leads one to the conclusion that perhaps, though moulded by our nurture, it is indeed our nature that is already planned out for us which we reveal piece by piece, with each successive leg of experience and experiences in life.

One think I know for sure is, I am meant for a simple life. Not simple in that I am a simple person, for I am one of the most complex people I know of, but simple as in that is what I crave, long for and have grown up to appreciate. Despite my sometime wild dreams of wealth and prosperity, down deep I realize the wealth I seek is wealth of life, the marrow, the experience, and prosperity in making a difference on the world I touch.

The movie Cast Away has stirred something inside of me I need to remind myself of more often--the value of simplicity, the necessity to re-evaluate what is really important, and how much our antibiotic, commercialistic, technology-driven society brainwashes us into thinking that if we buy into it, we'll fill a void that can truly only be filled by God, and self-knowledge that comes from *truly* living. This kind of living is one virtually unknown to our North American society but it is one based on need and necessity, and not greed and desire. And when it comes down to it, truly all we need to live is faith, sustenance, purpose and above all else, love.

When we stand at the cross roads of life, there are many paths we could take, and only one we will. As Frost suggests, I shall embark on the one least travelled. My life awaits me along the path, not at the end. ****************************

While you may think I haven't told you anything about the movie, this is everything the movie has purged from me.. and so maybe I've told you more than a plot summary could ever do. If you want an opinion, form your own by seeing it, and experiencing it. It may cause you to re-evaluate your self, and your life. Remember, the depth of the movie is only as deep as you allow it to penetrate, and it's strength comes from understanding that it's "Cast Away" and not "Castaway". "I know what I have to do now. I gotta keep on breathing, because the sun will rise in the morning, and you never know what the tide will bring." --Tom Hanks in "Cast Away"

title: Surprised
review:
My friends called me and asked me if I want to go to the movies. I said sure why not, what movie do you want to see? They said "Cast Away". At that point, here's why I thought:

1) I don't like Tom Hanks that much.

2) The movie is about him being lost on an island alone, which means it probably is boring.

But seeing that it's the no.1 movie on the boxoffice and that it's getting good reviews, I went along. The bottom line is: I enjoyed the movie. Of course it's not perfect, but it is well done in general.

TOM HANKS:

He did a good job. I didn't like some of his acting. For example, during the whole plane crash and when he was in the sea/waves/thunders right after, Tom Hanks didn't make a sound. Not even ONE SOUND, not a scream, not an "Oh My God", not a "Help", not a "AHH!!". I do not get it, for me it doesn't make sense. He must have been terrified during the crash and complete silence does not portray that. Other then that, I thought he did a good job although once again, the whole movie evolves around him. It's like he's the big star of the movie, who cares about the others. It's always like that in his movies, it's always about HIM. I am surprised the movie wasn't titled "Tom Hanks". But anyways, it's no big deal.

Also, as soon as he landed on the island, his actions weren't normal. He started screaming for help before even moving one meter and checking where he is. Anyways.

THE MOVIE:

There's not many scenes that I didn't like. I was entertained the whole time. Wilson must have payed huge money for this. There were some funny moments, some intense moments, drama, action. It's well-balanced.

All in all, I enjoyed the movie, and I recommend it to anyone. 8/10.

title: Does anyone know what Chuck went through?
review: WE saw the harrowing loneliness in which a volleyball becomes a muse and best friend.  But NO ONE in the film except perhaps the freighter crew that picked him up see him as anything but a little buffer upon his return.  The Helen Hunt reunion in the driveway was sad but not as poignant as it might have been.  Can some cracked crab from the FedEx HR department really make up for four years of nothingness?

title: Great performance by Hanks
review: Cast Away is a decent film about the survivor of a plane crash.  Tom Hanks proves his acting ability once more in a distinguished career, as he has over an hour of screen time by himself, with no actor to play off of and no musical score in the background.  Such a feat is nearly impossible to pull off without strong acting abilities.  The film is a little long, but the crash scene is very hauntingly real and the performance by Hanks is worth seeing.

title: Life is too short to live by the clock.
review:
Cast Away was a great movie - the emotion of the story of Tom Hanks (Chuck) rushing through every day life as a FedEx corporate Trainer and stating lines like "You live by the Clock" is so true. We all live by the clock in our fast busy every day lives of juggling careers, friends, and relationships. But life slowed Tom Hanks down in Cast Away - it snatched that clock right away from him and landed him on a deserted island to think about what is the importance in life. For him it was Kelly (Helen Hunt), his true love.

Tom Hanks was superb and his terror and fear ran through me in this movie. The cinema-photography was so vivid! The airplane crash was so real, the close up of Tom knocking his tooth out and the huge waves that crashed down on him was so real, vivid and placed me right there with him.

I rated the movie 8 Stars - I wanted to give it 10 stars, but the ending left me wanting more. The beginning and the middle of the movie were excellent and the ending was sweet - but so much more could have closed it.

You won't regret seeing Cast Away - I didn't!

title: Really good flick
review: I really enjoyed this movie.  It didn't have the best dialogue (well, of course not.  He was stranded alone on an island) and it didn't go into some aspects that I would have liked for it to have gone into, but it was definately captivating.  It is one of those movies that you would be willing to postpone going to the restroom just so you can see what's going to happen next.  I would give it a strong 8 on a 10 pooint scale.   (My wife gives it an 8.5)

title: It only seemed like four years.
review: Tom Hanks is a consummate professional who will go to whatever extreme necessary to be his character. His only flaw in this film is picking the script. Is it possible to sustain audience involvement for 60 minutes of one person on a deserted island - no people, no animals, not even snakes, lizards and bugs? Four years is a long time to watch a movie.

title: Cast Away Is An OK Movie
review: I went into this one skeptical because the critics liked it. With the exception of a very few, the movies critics applaud bore me to tears. This one was, in my opinion, a casualty until the crash. Hanks and Hunt walk through their lines in the beginning like they are just punching a time clock saying memorised lines. There is no passionate chemistry between them. In fact they are rather cool to each other not even acting like they like each other really except where it says "insert kiss here". The movie does take off however when Hanks boards the doomed flight and soars from then on. The rest of the movie is suspenseful, funny and poignant. Hanks is marvellous in his Robinson Caruso role. Hunt finally finds her emotions at the end and finally the chemistry between Hanks and Hunt is there for the ending. This one fell flat for me in the beginning but soared into the ending with flying colors.

title: Another gem from Hanks!
review:
I came out of the theater wondering how Mr. Hanks could have condensed so much emotion and depth into what potentially seemed an empty movie. I think it's his best work since Dragnet. People compare his everyman style to the great Jimmy Stewart, and rightly so. Whenever I saw Hanks working his magic, for example in the charming scenes with the volleyball, you could see the mantle of 'America's Actor' being passed from Stewart to Hanks. I have'nt seen that kind of chemistry between an actor and non-speaking prop since Hanks' previous triumph, Turner and Hooch.

The direction captured the isolation of Hanks and his surroundings, whilst keeping an understated feel. Definitely Zemeckis' best job since Death Becomes Her and Forrest Gump. My one gripe being that the most memorable part of the movie was the crash sequence. I had hoped that the director could have matured, and not rely on special effect action sequences to carry his movies. And the dialogue was adequate too. I could'nt decide between this and Boyles Jnr's other standout, Entrapment.

There was support from Hunt and Noth: I thought that their acting on the periphery, provided the necessary distance that enhanced Hanks' realistic portrayal of solitude. The same effect that Tawney Kitaen and Adrian Zmed had on Hanks in Bachelor Party. The 'far-off' co-acting in both films provided the chance for Hanks to shine in his solo star role amongst the driftwood.

The ending, when we find Hanks back in civilization, I felt did'nt keep with the tone and pace of the film. Although we are now used to the heart-warming rousing finales of Hanks' movies, who could forget the close-out of Splash, I would have preferred to have seen Hanks see out the film still on the island, with the volleyball.

In closing I would rate Cast Away quite well against the other 'stranded on an island' movies I have seen. Hanks' project deals with the issues of alienation and survival, whilst not losing sight of the potential of fate that can rescue people from isolation and put them back into a more favorable position. Similar to what $1 million did for Richard Hatch after the Survivor TV series. And not to point all the credit to Hanks, seen in the box-office returns for Cast Away, I do hope that his co-star in Big, Jared Rushton received a few points after showing Hanks the potential for a 'lost in the wilderness' vehicle, after he starred in a not too dissimilar picture, A Cry In The Wilderness.

A 'twerp cinema' rating of four.

title: Best Movie of the Year!
review: I just came back from "Cast Away" at the theater, & I was shocked out of my mind.  What I thought could have been an interesting diversion at the movies turned out to be a powerful, emotional, hilarious and fun holiday movie. The simple story, about a man's adventures stranded on a desert island, becomes an incredible drama that makes you feel for its characters.  Oscars all around!  Best Movie of the Year!

title: A Great movie that could have been Excellent except for...
review:
...one scene where the words "FOUR YEARS LATER" appear, in my opinion that's what can seperate a good director from a great director. If done well the audience should not have to be told it is 4 years later... we should already know it... again that is just my opinion, otherwise kudos to Tom for making this another "Must See" film. I was sitting in a theater getting ready to watch MEN OF HONOR, another good one, when the trailer for Cast Away came on, and I remember sitting there captured by the clips of the plane crash (I agree with another viewer, they did give too much of the movie away) and saying I have to see this.

Huge credit goes to Wilson, of course, "someone" I am sure we can all relate. I admired Tom's desire to get Wilson back and then making a conscious decision to give up the fight and move on... that was a very powerful momment... a very final momment that was beautifully done. I am glad Wilson did not wash up on shore, to me it would have decreased the impact of the significant role Wilson played.

All the scenes done without dialogue were excellent. You could here a pin drop in the theatre. Tom does a great job at telling a story without words. The shoe scene was FUNNY.. I think it was meant to be funny. Kind of makes you not want to take off your shoes in an airplane, which goes against Bruce Willis' theory about dealing jetlag (DIEHARD)

Overall a great movie and while I wasn't knocked out of socks about the ending I did appreciate the "realness" of it. The movie is worth the time spent... and finally it may be just me but I am not to sure I would be ready for another airplane that quick after what happened. But again, that's just my opinion.

title: good movie which could be much better
review:
This review contains some spoilers, nothing direct, just some references

I expected cast away to be an oscar winner. I do not believe it is going to win an oscar after i saw it

Few reasons:

The beginning was too long(they spend 10 useless minutes at the start which can be done better)

The ending was very weak with no point. Usually after someone thought to be dead for (a long time) company least going to keep his job

The island part i thought was the best part i seen this year. If they added more to it like him building home/adapting to the environment (maybe build some part where he keeps caught fish and other food(you cant expect him to only eat what he catches same day))

If they added those parts i think it be a great movie

Volleyball scenes were very good cause it kept him communicating(while some think of it as insanity, i believe it saved him from going insane (he believed the volleyball was like a person, so his decisions were based on them two (more rational/considerate))

I still think its a very well made movie, just not perfected as i have come to expect from Hanks movies

title: What's the point of cliff-notes trailers???
review:
Why, oh why did they give the whole movie away in the trailers and TV commercials? What could possibly have been the point? To get us to see it? I didn't need that. I was going to see it after viewing the first trailer months ago...you know the one where he lands on the island and yells "Hello,...anybody!!" and then it fades to black. That's all I needed. I was hooked right there. Yeah, Tom Hanks was great. Yeah, it was a good story, so what.

My whole experience of this movie was a big let down, because I knew what was going to happen. I'm sure others who say they didn't really enjoy the movie are feeling the disappointment stemming from this knowledge, as well. The only thing I didn't know for sure was what was going to happen after he got back to civilization...but I had a pretty good idea, and I was right, which was another disappointment. Predictability kills a movie for me. I don't want to know what's going to happen before I see it, and I certainly don't want the whole movie laid out for me in the trailer, as this one was...ridiculous.

I still can't believe it. If you've seen all the trailers for this movie, as I did, there was really no reason to see the movie in the theatre...because you've already seen it, in condensed form. Of course, by just seeing the trailers you don't get the full range and impact of emotion and the subtle nuances that drive the plot forward, and of course you miss the cinematography that makes the movie great to look at, as well as the remarkable physical transformation of Tom Hanks' character, but if you want to know what this movie is all about, and I do mean "all about", then the trailers are all you need.

I kept waiting for something to happen...some twist in the plot. Maybe he would come back and be unable to re-acclimate himself to civilization, or something...anything. But from the moment he came back, the movie sank into dismal predictability, heart-wrenching, yes, but predictable, just the same.

This seems to be a nasty trend in trailers, lately. Perhaps the rationale is the more they show in the trailer, the more will come to see the movie. Faulty logic, if you ask me. Once you have the fish on the hook, you don't keep throwing bait at it.

title: WOW
review:
When I first heard that Cast Away was about some guy who was stuck on an island for four years, I thought "Yah, that's sounds REAL exciting *sarcastic*" Then, I started to think "Well, Tom hanks is in it, how bad could it be?" So, I went to see it, and I was totally blown away. You know you've seen a great movie when you can't stop thinking about it for weeks after you've left the theater.

I still get tears in my eyes thinking about Chuck's will to survive in Cast Away. I can not even begin to fathom four years on an island - ALONE. I mean, this guy's only companion for four whole years is a volleyball. I think I'd forget how to speak English after that long there, but Chuck never loses his will to survive, and makes do with what he has. His memories of Kelly keep him alive, and like he says afterward, he just kept on breathing, kept on living. SPOILERS ALERT Three particularly striking moments in the movie were when he lost Wilson, when he said that he had lost Kelly when the plane crashed, then he had to lose her all over again when he was saved, and third, when he made fire. HE felt like the greatest man alive, and perhaps he was at the moment, or for the next four years.

Chuck loved his volleyball, it was his buddy, he talked to it, he argued with it, discussed with it, and then mourned over his losing it. Although he seems to lose so much in the movie, he has gained a much deeper understanding of himself and is in better touch with his soul and spirit. He has endured just about as much as anyone can, and lives though it.

The audience obviously finds itself wanting Chuck and Kelly to get back together, and we weep with Chuck when we realize that it cannot happen.

Who else is still wondering what became of the Christmas present (presumably an engagement ring) that Chuck gave to Kelly the last time he saw her, just before he got on the plane?

I think that his time on the island could have been a little more drawn out, and his relationship with Kelly more developed, but all in all, this was one of the most touching films I have ever seen. Forrest Gump is first on that list.

I have so much admiration for Tom Hanks. You not only leave his movies thinking for weeks about the plot, but thinking about his characters, admiring them, dreaming about them, relating to them, loving them. I would so much love to be an actress like that, and I have yet to find a female actor that I can look up to in that way. Acting is what I love to do most, and I will strive to do it in the fashion that Tom Hanks does. If I ever make it to the big screen, even for a second, I pray that it is beside Tom Hanks. THANK YOU TOM HANKS

title: One of the best thought provoking movies I have seen!!
review: It was without a doubt one of the best I have seen in a long time. It sure is a good idea that maybe Hollywood continue making real human stories. So sick and tired of violence and dumb space and other stupid plots. Never visited this site before and not sure why I have to fill in four lines to say a movie is great but here they are 5 lines.

title: Less action than expected, but a great story...
review: Cast Away is an interesting story that forces us to think.  There are many great shots and nicely crafted scenes in Cast Away, but what I think distinguishes it from most movies today is its willingness to show us a story rather than tell us what we should think and feel.  Although I would have liked to hear more of Hanks' own thought process, we're forced to look inward and see how Hanks' character parallels our life.  Following the movie we are forced to reflect how we would act if we were on the Island, what we would do if our only true love was lost for years only to reappear, and how relationships lived inside our heads are often perfect but rarely play out in reality.  These all happen here and Zemekis wisely enough doesn't show us how they should be resolved, but simply what happens to Hanks' character and how an everyday man copes with extraordinary circumstances both on and off a deserted island.

title: Worthwhile Mix of Primal Nature and Hollywood
review:
Well...hours later and I still haven't come to a conclusion about "Cast Away". Though a lengthy movie, it drags only in the last scenes, uncertain about whether a "happily ever after" or a more ambiguous ending would be more suitable. In the end, the makers split the difference, not completely satisfactorily.

However, let's deal with the stuff on the island and leave the Hollywood bits (and the incredible FedEx product placement) aside. I was enthralled by the isolation and Tom Hanks' performance and wished that there was more of it. Lots of small revelations, very worthwhile. Overall, I'd certainly recommend the movie, but a couple of points shy of the "10" the makers were shooting for.

title: This movie will leave you wondering why...
review:
As always, Tom Hanks gives us a wonderful performance. It's really easy to enjoy spending time with him alone on an island talking to a volley ball, but I don't know what they were thinking with the book ends they stuck on the movie.

I guess it comes back to my lack of enthusiasm for Helen Hunt (she plays Hanks' love interest in the movie)... or maybe just that things happen kind of fast. First we're in Russia and we see that Hanks is an enthusiastic Fedex employee. Then he's home for Christmas, then he's on a plane, then he crashes, then it's four years later, he escapes the island and next thing you know he's sitting on a plane going home to Memphis. And what's the point of making him grow that awesome beard when he shaves it off as soon as he gets back to the motherland?

I will say however that it's a good movie in that you barely notice that it lasts 2 1/2 hours, but it could have been so much better (I know it's easy to criticize, but keep in mind that I always extend props to those who work on features. It's a lot of work and they do it well). And please, stop casting Helen Hunt, she really ruins movies for me.

title: A perfect exegesis of the existential plight of man.
review:
This movie beautifully confronts the attentive viewer with the essential challenge of existence. We are alone and we must each find a reason to live and a means to do so.

Tom Hanks is outstanding as he has been before in the role of everyman. And the film doesn't wimp out with a happy neat all-is-resolved ending, much to Roger Ebert's consternation.

title: My spiritual connection with the movie, and my recommendations.
review: I thought Cast away was an incredible movie. The kind of movie that leaves you numb and motionless in your seat. The team of Robert Zemeckis as director and Tom Hanks as star once again, touched me in the same way that Forrest Gump with its epic style cinematography did before. The story of a man who is cast away from a life of convenience to a life of extreme conditions that test his will to survive. When I was watching the film I kept questioning myself, questioning my capabilities if I were thrown into the same situation. Would I fight to stay alive or just give up? I certainly wouldn't have relied on a volleyball, but it was a nice touch and this is a nice movie I'll give it 4 *'s a definate don't miss.

title: Good Movie, not great, but very good
review:
A fine, highly quality film. If you have not seen it, please do so.

It never quite achieves classic status, however. The best parts are of course the island scenes.

Unlike many other comments, I actually thought the end part of the movie was good. It basically makes the viewer think about his or her own life, as Chuck Noland does, at his cross roads, both literally and figuratively.

Once he returns, his path of life is again uncharted and open to anything. That is, except for any future with his love Helen Hunt.

Tom Hanks is simply the best all around actor. We are enjoying this man in the prime of his life. If nothing else, see the movie to see Hanks.

title: Wrung Out...
review:
Whew! What a film. I just got back from seeing "Cast Away", and I'm not quite able to put into words what I'm feeling right now. Suffice it to say that it was probably the most uniquely engaging film experience I have ever had at the movies. I never thought that a film with such a scarcity of dialogue through the central portion of the film could provoke such an emotional response from me, but this film pays off in buckets. When Tom Hanks' character felt pain, I felt it. When he experienced jubilation, I was right there with him. Additionally, the absence of a soundtrack score through a lot of the film enhances the experience that the main character goes through, and this minimalist approach forces the audience to focus on the bare essentials just as he does.

There seemed to be 3 distinct movements to the film, and the final movement I think might have been the most poignant, all due to the previous sections of the film. Without giving anything away, just know that when the final scene fades you feel a subtle elation that things turned out the way they did.

Also, the scene in the airplane earlier in the film treats you as if you're a passenger. Hanks' character never really knows what is happening or why it is happening, only that something is horribly wrong. Again, no music on the soundtrack, no additional dramatic flair, just a harrowing experience of the sort that I continue to fear whenever I have to fly somewhere. (On reflection, this scene probably wasn't good for me, and I hope I conveniently forget it!)

This film did not evoke too many tears for me during the actual duration of it (although it had some very real moments that I can't forget), but what it did do was leave me sorting out the details long after it was over. If a movie can do that, it was more than worth the price of a ticket. This one does, and is.

title: Hanks Rescues
review:
There are some spoilers, so be warned.

To use the words of Adam Sandler in a memorable Saturday Night Live sketch, "Who are the ad wizards who came up with this one?" If you've seen a commercial or a trailer for Cast Away, you basically know everything that happens, including the ending. This ass-backwards marketing campaign almost ruined what could have been an incredibly suspenseful and absorbing film, but Cast Away is still to be appreciated for the tremendous performance of Tom Hanks.

Hanks plays Chuck Noland, a FedEx manager who is so devoted to his job that he spends Christmas not with his fiancee Kelly (Helen Hunt), but on a cargo plane flying over the South Pacific. The plane crashes, and Chuck washes up on a deserted island as the sole survivor. The scenes on the island are fascinating, because director Robert Zemeckis and writer William Broyles never cheat the premise. This is not Swiss Family Robinson, with an elaborate treehouse and monkey butlers; Chuck has only his ingenuity and the contents of a few washed-up FedEx packages to rely on. To further create the feeling of isolation, Zemeckis includes very little music, and the only dialogue is between Chuck and "Wilson" (a volleyball found in one of the packages). Wilson, in fact, deserves a place as one of the most memorable inanimate objects in film history, alongside Rosebud the sled, the Red Ryder BB gun from A Christmas Story, and Keanu Reeves.

Tom Hanks is basically asked to carry the film by himself, since if the audience doesn't care about Chuck, they won't care about the movie. The key to the performance is that Hanks takes it completely seriously; when he is trying to start a fire, you can see the intensity and desperation in his eyes as he rubs the sticks together. When he finally gets a flame going, he dances in joy and sings an endearingly off-key version of "Light My Fire" by the Doors. The audience identifies with Chuck as an average (if very smart) Joe. It is no secret that Hanks is a talented actor, but his performance in Cast Away is a step beyond anything that he has done before; he may well win his third Oscar for the role.

The scenes on the island are so good, in fact, that the final act of the film is anti-climactic. I won't spoil the ending, even though the studio did it themselves, but Zemeckis gets a little too arty for his own good. Though the point of the final scene seems to be that life goes on, there should still be come kind of finality to the movie.

Since the ending is common knowledge, Cast Away becomes more like a James Bond movie; you know that Bond is going to win in the end, it's just a matter of how he does it. Hanks and Zemeckis do such a good job of building suspense, however, it's a shame to see the film reduced to a formula.

7/10

title: A shameless FedEx Commercial with a great advertisement for Wilson sporting goods thrown in!
review: I am outraged at watching this horrible sell-out movie that serves the purpose of making money and promoting FedEx as a saintly company. It starts out watching the efficent delivery of a package. Then Tom Hanks giving speeches about packages not even being a minute late and FedEx can not be like the postal service. Hell, the movie makes it painfully obvious he cares more about FedEx then his girl. Then the FedEx plane crashes. He is stranded and FedEx packages float to shore and save him. On the way he makes friends with a wilson volleyball and the sell-out director even goes low enough to name the ball "wilson", so you can be reminded what brand the freaking ball is! Then he gets back on a FedEx plane. FedEx people give speeches about him. Then after breaking up his girl, he goes to deliver a FedEx package. This delivery of the package that "saved" his life, leads him to another romantic interest just in the nick of time. What am I saying? FedEx is god. This movie warped my fragile little mind. I can't wait until all movies, songs and book are about companies!

title: Like drinking a warm, flat soft drink.
review:
This film is just like that. It is good if your desperate, and it doesn't contain anything awful, but you could have better and it leaves you unsatisfied and you wouldn't want to have it again.

I liked Tom Hanks in this, but would just as well see him in something like Apollo 13 or Forest Gump. There were a few creative and entertaining elements here and there, but the ending was bad.

So his girlfriend got with some other guy and married him. Big deal. He was gone for 4 years, did he just expect her to wait by the phone for all that time?

In closing, you'll probably see the film, but don't make the mistake that I did: going in with high expectations!!!

title: Perfect movie ruined by Weak Ending (Spoilers)
review:
Just got back from seeing CastAway. It started out slow and dull, not really going anywhere. Then Hanks gets stuck on the island, and the movie comes to life. Every single second spent on the island (probably 2/3 of the movie) is great. I think Wilson should be up for an academy award. Seriously though, heres why.

Once Hanks gets off the island, the movie starts to go downhill. I was hoping for a TRANSITION of how Hanks returns to society. But there is absoulutley ZERO transition.

By the end of the movie, the person who has gone through the most change is Wilson. Born in a box, he lived his life and tragically was lost at sea, buy the point I am trying to make is that he CHANGED the most out of anyone, and he was a *&@#($#!! vollyball.

I am still giving this movie a 7/10, because the middle was so INCREDIBLE. I'll end it on a good note by saying this. The shot where Tom is looking over the edge of the summit is one of the most beautiful shots I have seen in a hollywood film.

title: Another good movie shot to hell by the trailers!
review:
Another good effort shot to hell by its trailers. [If you have NOT seen any trailers to this movie, YOU must be alone on a desert island! But if so, stop reading and go see it; it's a good movie that you'll enjoy, but hurry before you watch another minute of tv.]

***SPOILERS (only if you have not seen any trailers)***

What didn't you know about this movie going in? Except, perhaps, that Helen Hunt had a small, almost insignificant role? You knew that Hanks would be "right back," then a crash landing left him on a desert island for several years; you knew he would be declared dead and that Hunt's memory would keep him alive; you knew he would make it back; you knew that Hunt would be married when he did; and you knew going in that it was going to be a shameless commercial for FedEx and Wilson sporting goods -- to the point that you kept asking, why?

Having said that, you really DO think that Tom Hanks has been stranded on a remote island with little or no clue as to how to survive. You really DO think that he is losing his mind. He's a fine actor, and the long stretches of tedium highlight the fact that life on a desert island is anything but glamorous.

When I was in line for tickets, the woman in front of me asked for tickets for "The Castaways." Now, I knew this wasn't a Disney retread, but it made me look at the marquee. And there it was. It not only wasn't plural, it wasn't even singular. Cast Away's a verb, not a noun! Now, that says more about the movie than almost anything else.

Odd ending that few will like. People like finality; this movie didn't give it. 7 of 10.

title: Great acting, dopey script
review:
Cast Away is sure to nab another Oscar nomination for Tom Hanks, and in a relatively weak year for film he may just win his third. He would deserve it, and not just for his physical transformation. Any other actor in the world would get laughs if they recited the dopey dialogue (or monologue, I guess, since he's alone on that island). I can't imagine Ralph Finnes being taken seriously if he proclaimed "I have made . . .fire!" but Hanks somehow pulls it off.

You may be aware that the studio moronically gives away the ending in the trailers and commercials--it is inexcusable and blunts much of the emotion of the situation. This is a solid film with a fascinating second and third acts, but a flat-footed fourth act. They paint themselves into a corner with no satisfactory ending, and then fail to come up with a satisfactory conclusion. But with Hanks' acting and Zemeckis' eye-popping direction, this film is very satisfying.

title: What was in the Fedex box?
review: Tom Hanks once again proves his superior acting abilities as he holds the audience's attention for the movies entire length.  From Moscow to the remote pacific island the audience was engulfed with truly powerful settings and human emotions.  The only question that was left in the audience's mind was, "What was in the Fedex box?".  I believe that the ending would have been better served with a bit more finality.   However, I feel it was a bit too open.  I would have liked more of a climatic ending.  But with that said, my congratulations to Mr. Hanks for another wonderful and refreshing movie going experience.

title: An amazing experience.
review:
The best way to describe "Cast Away" is that it isn't a movie, it's an experience. It seems like so much more than just a movie, it is almost like you are living on the island with Tom Hanks. For the duration of the film I found myself totally lost in it. I was also a cast away.

There are a few films which are able to have just one brilliant moment in the whole picture. "Cast Away" contains several, if not the entire movie itself. The plane crash is one of the most intense scenes in recent memory, and rivals anything in "The Perfect Storm." The scenes where Chuck (Hanks) is trying to make a fire have a desperation and perseverance that accompany them. The raft scenes are also outstanding and incredibly suspenseful.

The best part of "Cast Away" is no doubt Tom Hanks. I have never seen an actor carry a film on his shoulders like Hanks does. The majority of the film is Hanks, and only Hanks. It takes an amazing performance to pull something like that off, and he delivers. His emotional state throughout his time on the island changes, and he doesn't have to say anything. It's all in the eyes and the body language. Tom Hanks may not beat Russell Crowe for best actor, but a nomination is assured.

The mastermind behind "Cast Away" is none other than Robert Zemeckis. He directs with patience and maturity. He allows Hanks the breathing room to make the tedious island scenes work. I have not seen editing this effective since "JFK." He delivers a movie with a lot of suspense and drama. The film's end is one of the best I've ever seen, and really is appropriate.

Go to the theater and experience "Cast Away." Remember to bring your beach towel and sun block.

title: Cast Awesome!
review: This is truly the best film Tom Hanks has made since "Philadelphia". The story is great. It really makes you think about your own life and the choices that we each have made in our lives, and how a decision as small as answering his beeper changed his life.

title: A Movie to get you thinking
review: Cast Away was truly one of those movies that gets a person thinking.  I sat there through the whole movie just wondering what I would do if I was in the situation.  Also, Tom Hanks did a marvelous job in this movies.  It could be one of the best roles he has ever done.  Finally Wilson the volleyball was my second favorite actor in the movie.

title: As flat as the screen you read from
review:
Rarely do I write a review about a film I see, but I found it necessary to warn viewers of a film that is this repulsive and disastrous. The first 20 minutes of the film are a big commercial for FedEx (as you have seen in the trailer). Then, in a (I must admit, exciting) sequence, his (FedEx) plane goes down in the Atlantic Ocean.

Now the film gets REALLY dull. We see Tom Hanks play Survivor's Richard Hatch (with, thankfully, more clothes on), for a full hour where he talks to Wilson (enter the advertisement), his new friend VOLLEYBALL!

Then, you can brace yourself for the last grueling 23 minutes, and come out of the theater feeling like you just survived a plane crash yourself.

In conclusion, basically, Hollywood screwed up. The film is as flat as a news broadcast. If you want to see it purely for Tom Hanks extraordinary acting, good luck.

Be Warned: Seeing films without a plot can be hazardous...

title: Intense, emotionally gripping film
review: Wow, what an unbelievable film. This movie truly shows how much we should value our everyday interactions with people and situations which we may take for granted. Great action, and great acting by Hanks which may give him another Oscar for this role.

title: What a ball...
review: Cast Away would have been just another holiday movie if not for the exceptional breakthrough performance of one individual...Wilson the volleyball.  He steals every scene he appears in.  We weep with him as he's booted out of the cave.  His final scene at sea was so emotional I had to excuse myself from the theater.  Despite rumors of difficulties on set, I found him to work quite well with Hanks, their onscreen chemistry held the audience raptly.  I foretell a great future for this talented volleyball.

title: if you haven't seen it...
review:
... I would stop reading reviews and just go see this movie. Go. The less you know the better.



















are you still here? Good, then you must've seen it. Then you'll probably agree that Tom Hanks did a great job. I think that you'll agree that all the Tom Hanks scenes on the island made the movie what it was... but then he makes it back. And that's where the movie becomes questionable. I liked some things, and others I really disliked and for me... it almost made it a thumbs down. Endings can make or break a film... and many people will say the ending works and you'll love this movie. But I think my expectations were too high and I was displeased with the ending. But the more I think about the movie, especially the scenes with Tom getting off the island and music coming back into the movie... it's still a good movie and worth seeing.

title: Good, but Disappointing
review:
What saves this film is good acting. There is no real plot, very little dialog, and the story depends entirely on our ability to believe Hanks's character.

I've heard and read a lot about the ending being disappointing, but little as to why. The reason has to do with the fact that they telegraph the ending near the beginning, when Hanks decides not to open a particular FedEx package because of the hand-drawn design on the outside. That in itself, for me, was extremely hard to swallow. A man or woman fighting for survival will use ANY means, and so many of the other packages (virtually every one of them) had something he could use.

And so, I ask myself, why are we left to wonder at the end what was in the package? Has the screenwriter no sense of irony? Are we supposed to believe that a pair of wings drawn on a package represent some sort of guardian angel metaphor? Thin. VERY thin.

It it weren't for Hanks (and yes, Hunt, whose smallish part was just as brilliant as Hanks's) bringing sheer brute-strength acting skills so this film, it would have little to recommend it.

The fact that I was disappointed by an ending they revealed so early in the film is why I couldn't give it a high rating. Filmmaking, after all, is about story telling, not just about acting. The story suffered, and so by extension, so did the movie.

In summary, I found it, overall, to be emotionally unsatisfying.

-- TRegner

title: Unopened FedEx package - something isn't right here
review:
Ok, the movie opens with a artist's package being picked up in Texas and delivered to Russia (the wife sends something to the husband and he answers the door in his cowboy hat and with his mistress in tow).

Tom Hanks is one a FedEx plane to Malaysia and crashes and finds a package from this same women from Texas. Now while its possible that this artist sends her work via FedEx worldwide, what are the chances of her sending one package to Russia where Tom happens to be that day AND sending one to Malaysia on a flight he happens to be on!

title: A Mixed Bag
review: A good idea but not taken far enough.  The plot is painfully predictable once we realise he's eventually going to be saved.  The most interesting developments were those on the island.  A 'stranded' movie would have been more interesting.  The rest of the movie serve as cheap white bread that sandwiches a good piece of meat.  The whole project smells of uncertainty and indecision.

title: Very good, avoids most expected pitfalls
review:
This was a very satisfying movie, and Tom Hanks once again shows that he is a fine choice for serious treatments of characters who are alone/isolated one way or another. I should mention that my comments wil l focus on several plot points, so SPOILER ALERT! (as if the trailers left much out.)

The Setup: The movie takes planty of time to show that Hanks character is a type-A go-getter, always zipping around the world, no time for anything, addicted to his cell phone and pager. This makes the isolation and barren local of the island (good for the producers that they found a truely tiny one, as made clear from Hanks first peek from the summit) a perfect contrast. Some other user comments complained that there was not enough 'action' in the film, but teenagers apparently miss concept that it is the boredom and isolation that is the whole point. The interest comes from how he will use his native resourcefulness to cope.

The Crash: there were two aircraft disasters, the storm and the explosion, and that one would have been sufficient. Obviously, the storm is required so that the crash will take place far away from where the searchers will eventually look. The explosion is required so that the plane crashes. The storm cannot account for the crash since the pilots have gone around the worst of it, as they would really do, and this film is trying to be realistic. Same with the explosion...these things DO happen, as we know from ValueJet! The crash seems pretty realistic, and the floating pieces or wreckage are consistant with real plane ditchings. My only beef is that the jet engine would almost certainly NOT still be running.

The Homelife: Some have complained that the happenings back home are not shown concurrently with Hank's island vacation. The movie does it right...Hanks is the character we see the film through, and he obviously has no idea whats going on elsewhere. We find things out when he does...once again, realistic.

The Unopened Package: Beside setting up the final scene, this makes some kind of sense for Hanks to leave at least one FedEx parcel alone. His whole personality is based on getting packages to their owners in a speedy and reliable manner. It was clear to me from the situation and setup of the scene that Hanks views the final package as a reason to survive. He needs to get at least one through in the end. Also, pay close attention to the scene in the beginning where the package from Texas is delivered to an obvious American in Moscow, who is cheating on his wife. Pay close attention at the end where Hanks arrives to deliver the unopened package... notice the change in the sign at the ranch. There is really very little left to doubt here.

The Fed Ex Placement: According to articles, the producers wanted authenticity and a sense of reality for their film. They felt that they needed a real cargo carrier, not a made-up one. UPS said no, they don't like people thinking about packages lost in a crash. FedEx said yes, but was reportedly not paid for this nor did they pay the producers. This does not then qualify as the usual product placement that Hollywood indulges in.

Overall, a well thoughout and realized movie for serious viewers.

title: One of Best this Year
review:
Everyone I saw this with, our group and the rest of the theater, was enthralled. This isn't a movie that spoon-feeds all its meaning to you, you have to pay attention and think.

Hanks's does an amazing portrayal: from shock, to determination to escape, to frustration, desolation, fear, through despair, a kind of reversion to primitive nature, and bare grip on the edge of sanity (from isolation). The movie really explores issues of humanity, community and human need, without preaching it. It's why I liked Saving Private Ryan better than The Thin Red Line. 'Ryan' had every bit as much to say about war and its effects, but let you figure it out. I would have to disagree with some comments, such as that Hanks should have had time to enjoy the natural wonders--not when mere survival is your full-time, every waking minute job, and nature can easily be the enemy. Also, Hanks does explore as much as is physically possible, you see everything he can see from that summit, and there is only one beach. I think the intensity comes from the whole movie (except first few minutes) being entirely from his vantage point; I would not have wanted to see what was going on 'back home'. I also can't imagine why there ever would have been any other human on this volcanic outcropping hundreds of miles from nowhere, so I'm not sure what good a skeleton in the cave would have done.

SPOILER REBUTTAL AND COMMENT It was not the view of any in our group that he replaced Hunt with the redhead. He was at the last looking down a different road, the one toward California. The ending didn't *feel* satisfying, but I can't say it was *unsatisfactory*. Hunt was ambivalent about commitment at the beginning, and still ambivalent at the end. She was consistent in that way. Hanks was, in a way, still adrift; only knowing that the sun will rise tomorrow.

title: This was almost perfect.
review: This movie was great. They executed the plane crash excellently. I laughed a lot in it, too. I'm not going to give anything away, but, I think the ending wasn't good at all. It wasnt enough for me. But, I would recommend going to see it.

title: The better side of Zemeckis
review: We take our lives for granted.  It may be normal and ordinary for us to use the instruments of necessities.  The 21st century man and woman have molded with technology to survive.  But what if all of the daily use of equipment is taken away from you, would you survive?  With Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks) he has to escape the modern technology world and survive with very little in the new film, CAST AWAY. Chuck Noland is a Fed Ex employee who has very little time, he dictates some Russians on how speed does make a difference when it comes to delivering a package.  Anc Chuck doesn't even have much time to spend the Christmas holiday with his love, Kelly Frears (Helen Hunt) since Chuck has to go overseas to help aid another Fed Ex station.  On route back to the U.S., over the south Pacific the jumbo Fed Ex cargo plane crashes killing the all of the crew and nearly killing Chuck.  Chuck then arrives on a deserted island, realizing that a man who was rushing with time, now has all the time in the world as he is isolated from civilization.  Chuck has to find ways to survive, he writes on a giant boulder with a smaller stone, he spears fishes with a sharp bamboo stick, and it is almost a miracle when he starts a fire.  With some Fed Ex boxes from the crash arriving on shore, Chuck makes the best use of them. He uses video tape for rope, a garment for a fishing net, and for companionship to keep his sanity he uses a volleyball as a head and names the ball "Wilson." I predicted back in July that CAST AWAY was going to be the better Robert Zemeckis film compared to WHAT LIES BENEATH (don't believe me, check out my WHAT LIES BENEATH review).  And several months later I was right, CAST AWAY was far much better than WHAT LIES.  I really enjoyed the symbolism of CAST AWAY, how can modern man survive in the wild. Zemeckis goes into much detail on how difficult it took the character of Chuck Noland to survive, with eating, shelter, and sanity. Zemeckis also shows some pretty graphic scenes on how Nick gets rid of a bad tooth. The movie is 138 minutes, and a little over a hour has Hanks alone on the island.  And to carry a movie like this, a great actor needs to do a excellent performance, and Tom Hanks does it very well!  Leave it to Tom Hanks to give another brillant performance in this film, which I feel should probably be his third Oscar win.  Along with PHILADELPHIA, FORREST GUMP, BIG, APOLLO 13, and SAVING PRIVATE RYAN, the role of Chuck Noland is a memorable performance in Hanks' career.  Hanks adds humor, sadness, and pain as the role of the sole survivor who goes through a adventure to survive. And what a adventure!  There are plenty of exciting scenes to keep any viewer's attention through out the entire movie.  I would like to see Kelly, Rudy, and Richard from t.v.'s "Survivor" to have the same necessities that Chuck has in the film to survive the island for about five years. The only flaw is that there are some scenes that have the adventures similar to a thrill ride, but there are some very slow scenes here and there. But why bicker?  CAST AWAY is easily one of the best films of 2000, and another excellent film to add to the impressive list of Tom Hanks' career.  Just like FORREST GUMP, the partnership of Robert Zemeckis and Tom Hanks would deliver a great film, and CAST AWAY is another film that delivers.  Don't miss it!  ***** (out of five)

title: This was an incredible movie.
review: Despite this film's length, it never lost my attention.  I was completely engaged in the "deserted" experience.  I thought it was a good call to not cut away to shots of the "real world", and I am also a fan of the nebulous ending.  And who doesn't like Tom Hanks?

title: Another good one from Hanks, Zemeckis.
review: This is one of the best films in a year of mostly oscar-unworthy productions.  Tom Hanks and Robert Zemeckis crank out another great movie worth seeing following the success of Forrest Gump several years ago. Cast Away is a significant improvement over Zemeckis' last creation, "What Lies Beneath", and Hanks turns in a performance that could score him a third Oscar.  It was certainly a dramatic risk for Hanks, who spends over an hour in the movie acting alone, with no costars and no background music.

title: Sadly, not all can appreciate this movie...
review:
I saw Cast Away for the 2nd time tonight and I was amazed at what I had missed the first time. Everything made me love it even more than I did before. Unfortunately, not everyone in the theater shared my sentiment. Several left with only 15 minutes to go and one idiot even yelled how much the movie "sucked." To ignorant people like these, I suppose Wilson was just a volleyball, not an object to represent Chuck's rational side and will-power survive on the island. His drifting away signaled that Chuck no longer needed him; he had fought on and now he was to be rescued. Many griped that Chuck should have opened the winged package. Why? Here was his FedEx instincts at work and his commitment to never turn his back on time. Who cares what was inside?! Anyway, I could go on forever about all the symbolism in this movie, but I'll give that a rest.

Everything in Cast Away was superb: the acting, the script, the awesome cinematography, and of course, Bob Zemeckis's wonderful direction. Tom Hanks should at least be nominated for Best Actor, but I doubt he'll get it. In any case, his brilliant work really carried the movie when there wasn't much verbal communication.

Well, if you're reading this and have seen the movie, I hope you can relate to what I am saying. If you haven't seen it, then definitely go, but only if you can appreciate this movie for its depth and presentation of the relentlessness of the human spirit. Otherwise, you are likely to be disappointed.

title: Weeks later, still thinking
review:
Unlike most modern movies, this does not spoon-feed the audience its symbolisms and meanings. This is something that needs to be thought over - I am looking forward to seeing it again to iron out the details. Without being too repetitive, yes, the plane crash is excellent and very realistic. And the ending is deceptively simple. It feels like it leaves you hanging, but in reality leaves everything wide open for interpretation. Just like Tom Hank's character is faced with a myriad of possibilities, both on and off the island, so is the viewer at the conclusion of this film.

slight spoiler ahead...

The only comment I have to add seems to have been missed by every other reviewer, or else they do not consider it important. Remember the card that is read on the island...it is something like "The most beautiful thing in the world is the world itself". Given the situation on the island, the "whale encounter", and a few other minor details, I think that this comment sums up the movie...a movement away from materialism and the stress of everyday life, and onto something more meaningful.

title: Good film, pathetic ending.
review: Cast Away is good, that's true. I knew exactly what it would be all about even before seeing it. But I still had fun. And the plane crash is awesome...freaky to death. The moments spent on the island were purely great, but the rest suffered of the Spielberg-like pathetic ending. Tom Hanks played his usual role, but who cares? He plays it well. Maybe a change wouldn't be so bad...Anyways, his character was pretty intelligent and he reacted just like I would have reacted...except for the swear words...he didn't even say one F-word. And Zemeckis really convinced me that Tom Hanks' Volley ball was his friend...I even felt stupid after the movie because of that. The backgrounds made me feel like I was in paradise. And this film is an exception to his genre, and it's a very good thing; He was always alone on his island, there were no stupid cannibal tribes or anything. It's like Robinson Crusoe, but with its own advantages, and its own weak points. This is surely a good movie, and I'm sure it will get some Academy Award Nominations, because it's exactly the kind of films that will touch the heart of the judges and please to their "Right to Censorship" mind. Most of it was a good moment, but the other parts suffered of the pathetic syndrome. And, by the way, this is not a very touching movie, it won't make you cry or anything, but it's very agreeable to watch. And you can also interpret it as a critic to materialism. Good film. 7/10

title: The return of the silent film (sort of)
review:
Warning: this may contain spoilers.

If you watch the current trailer for "Cast Away," you might go in expecting this Indiana Jones-style exotic action/adventure film. Dreamworks is selling something they're not delivering on, which is a mistake. No matter how good the film is, many viewers are going to feel duped. I didn't. Yes, it moved slower than I thought it would. That's only because I've come to expect differently from a major studio. Films that seem to have a lot at stake tend to worry too much about the audience feeling things like bored and impatient. The result is a rushed story that ends up disappointing anyway.

"Cast Away" actually trusts its audience. That's why at the end I really felt like applauding. I'd just been shown something great and meaningful. Except, to my surprise, no one else clapped (I am by nature shy, so I let the opportunity pass). I can't say I blame anyone either.
